fields.english: Someone who cries in the house, will also cry at the door, it's the same thing.
fields.creole: A body wah cry a-house, an'a body wah cry a-doo', a same t'ing

fields.english: Somebody they don't want to roast, nor to sit down near the fire.
fields.creole: A body wah dem no wan' fo' roas', no fo' si' down carnah fiah

fields.english: The colony hare knows his teeth are strong; that's why he eats the seed of the awarra palm.
fields.creole: Accouri know he teet' 'trang; da mek he eat banga

fields.english: The colony hare took the alligator's teeth and made sugar cake.
fields.creole: Accouri tek cayman teet' he mek sugah cake

fields.english: I came for milk from the cow, not to count the cattle.
fields.creole: A come fo' milk cow, no fo' reckon cattle

fields.english: A cow that cries for water is in need of it.
fields.creole: A cow wah cry fo' watah na he a-want am

fields.english: The dog has the freedom to watch the governor.
fields.creole: A daag hab libaty fo' watch a-de gubnah

fields.english: A dog's mouth makes it unable to climb a tree.
fields.creole: A daag mout' mek he can't climb tree

fields.english: After night, morning comes
fields.creole: After night ma'nin' come

fields.english: A gold made the white man die with yellow fever today.
fields.creole: A gold mek Bacra a dead wid yalla febah t'day

fields.english: A good friend is better than money in the pocket.
fields.creole: A good frien' is bettah dan money in de pocket

fields.english: It's hard to pay for music when you don't hear the banjo play.
fields.creole: A hard t'ing fo' pay fo' music when you no heah banja play

fields.english: A good heart makes a man ride it as he likes.
fields.creole: A hass, good heart mek man a-ride am as he like

fields.english: A hint to Benab to make Quashiba take notice.
fields.creole: A hint to Beniba mek Quashiba tek notice

fields.english: A little is better than nothing.
fields.creole: A little is bettah dan not'in.'

fields.english: All birds can sing, but not all birds can talk.
fields.creole: All bi'd can sing, but a11 bi'd can't talk

fields.english: All carrion crows eat dead meat, but not all dogs eat it.
fields.creole: All carrin crow a-nyam dead meat, but all dag na a-nyam am

fields.english: All cassava has the same skin, but they don't all taste the same way.
fields.creole: All cassada got same 'kin, but all na tas'e same way

fields.english: All cows cry, but not all cows butt.
fields.creole: All cow a-cry, but na all cow a-butt

fields.english: All dogs can bark, but some are afraid to bite.
fields.creole: All daag can bark, but some frighten fo' bite

fields.english: Anyone can talk foolishly, but not everyone can understand.
fields.creole: All fool can talk, but na all can heah

fields.english: The high bed is not safe.
fields.creole: All high bed no saf.'

fields.english: Alligator and cayman, they are the same thing.
fields.creole: Alligittah an' cayman, a11 same t'ing

fields.english: The alligator doesn't give his children suck, but they live.
fields.creole: Alligittah no a-gie he picknie suck, but dem lib

fields.english: The alligator eats frogs for a full belly, and ducks for a sweet mouth.
fields.creole: Alligittah nyam crapaud fo'belly full, an' duck fo' sweet mout'

fields.english: The alligator saw a bird, and he said it was a fish.
fields.creole: Alligittah see fowl, he say a fish

fields.english: All kinds of pleasure must come to a stop.
fields.creole: All kin' ob plesha mus' get wan 'taff-aff

fields.english: Everyone can talk, but not everyone can do.
fields.creole: All man can talk, but na all can do

fields.english: All pork father musty, but not all the time.
fields.creole: All po'k favah matty, but na all a-season

fields.english: Not everything sweet is sweet, not everything bitter is bitter.
fields.creole: All sweet na sweet, all bittah na bittah

fields.english: A man who doesn't know what he wants is a fool.
fields.creole: A man no know he own want is a fool

fields.english: Unlucky birds often get caught in unlucky traps.
fields.creole: Anlucky bi'd often get anlucky trap

fields.english: Ants know that hard times are coming, that's why they carry plenty of food to put in their house.
fields.creole: Ants know hard time a-come, da mek he does carry plenty food fo' put a-he house

fields.english: The fish live in the water, and the blue fly lives there.
fields.creole: A place fish watah deh, a de blue fly lib

fields.english: A place where rats scratch you, you see them for a slice, where he stands, you don't see him.
fields.creole: A place weh rat 'crape you a-see am fo' slice, weh he 'tan' up you no a-see am

fields.english: A pound of fretment doesn't pay a gill of debtment.
fields.creole: A pound ob fretment no pay a gill of debtment

fields.english: The same place where the thorn pricks your foot, is the same place you must take it out.
fields.creole: A same place pimplah chook you' foot, a same place you must take am out

fields.english: A spider senses danger when a monkey goes to kill, he starts to shout for the gunman to come.
fields.creole: A sense nancy bin got when monkey go fo' kill, he halla gun man a-come

fields.english: The ashes are cold, the dog is lying down there.
fields.creole: Ashes col', daag lie down deh

fields.english: As he can stand, so stands his heart.
fields.creole: As he 'kin 'tan', so 'tan' he heart

fields.english: As long as the school missy and school master are there, what you don't know today, you will know tomorrow.
fields.creole: As long as school missy an' school massa deh, wha' you no know t'day you sa know to-morrow

fields.english: A tiger's size and intelligence make him live in the bush today.
fields.creole: A tigah bigness an' sense mek he lib a-bush to-day

fields.english: When the sun goes down, the fowl doesn't scratch for its chicken, it scratches for itself.
fields.creole: A time sun a-down fowl no a-grabble fo' he chicken, ya grabble fo' hese'f

fields.english: I watch your dirty mouth, and I know how your house looks inside.
fields.creole: A watch a-you' doo' mout', an' me know how you' house inside 'tan'

fields.english: We live in the bush
fields.creole: Awe lib a-bush

fields.english: We two stubborn people can't agree on the same path.
fields.creole: Awe two coo-coo can't tu'n in de same pat

fields.english: The baby was born, his feet are small.
fields.creole: Baby born, he foot small

fields.english: Your back can wait, but your stomach cannot.
fields.creole: Back can wait, but no belly

fields.english: The white man saw the sideline dam before he walked a mile walk there.
fields.creole: Bacra bin see side-line dam befo' he walk a mi'l-walk dam

fields.english: The white person is just like cow dung, his top is dry, his bottom is wet.
fields.creole: Bacra jus' like cow-down, he tap dry, he battam wet

fields.english: A white person is not a boy, and a black person is not a fool.
fields.creole: Bacra no boy, niggah no fool

fields.english: White people don't talk, black people don't understand
fields.creole: Bacra no talk, niggah no sabby

fields.english: The white man stood like a doctor, he found a sweet flower on the ground and a tree.
fields.creole: Bacra 'tan' like dactah-bi'd, he fin sweet flower 'pon mo' 'an wan tree

fields.english: The bad cow gave a bucketful of milk and then kicked it down.
fields.creole: Bad cow gie bucketful milk an' kick am down

fields.english: A bad heart cannot practice witchcraft.
fields.creole: Bad heart no obeah

fields.english: Bad musician made noise with his foot.
fields.creole: Bad musicianer mek row wid he foot

fields.english: A bad reputation doesn't kill a rat.
fields.creole: Bad name no a-kill rat

fields.english: Bad people never have owners
fields.creole: Bad nebbah gat ownah

fields.english: The bag is not full, he can't stand up.
fields.creole: Bag no full, he can't 'tan' up

fields.english: The baker says his bread is sour.
fields.creole: Bakah nebhah Say 'e bread sour

fields.english: Make a deal before the country takes it
fields.creole: Bargain mek befo' country tek

fields.english: The boat doesn't have a keel, that's why it can't take plenty of sail.
fields.creole: Bateau know he na gat keel, da mek he can't tek plenty sail

fields.english: The boat without water is blowing "whoo-whoo" and moving.
fields.creole: Battle berout watah a-blow "whoo-whoo" a-win'

fields.english: The boat broke down, and the water leaked out.
fields.creole: Battle bore, watah run out

fields.english: But trust yourself to make it hang on top of the raft.
fields.creole: Bat trus' hese'f mek he heng a-raftah tap

fields.english: Beef has no bone, a dog has no business there.
fields.creole: Beef no ha' bone, daag no ha' no bu'iness deh

fields.english: Before, face like butter can't melt, behind back fire stick.
fields.creole: Befo' face like a buttah can't melt, behind back fiah 'tick

fields.english: Before farther, behind farther
fields.creole: Befo' farra, behin' farra

fields.english: Before the wedding, it's "my dear," after the wedding, it's "you brute."
fields.creole: Befo' wedding is "my dear," after wedding is "you brute.''

fields.english: The beggar is looking for work, but he is praying not to get it.
fields.creole: Beggah a-look fo' wo'k, but he a-pray fo' no get am

fields.english: A beggar who begs from another beggar will never become rich.
fields.creole: Beggah beg from beggah nebbah grow rich

fields.english: Beg for work, but don't beg for food
fields.creole: Beg man fo wo'k, but na beg am fo' eat

fields.english: Behind the back, no one has ears
fields.creole: Behin' back no hab ear

fields.english: A person who is full tells a hungry person, "Keep heart, friend."
fields.creole: Belly-full man tell hungry man, "keep heart buddy

fields.english: Belly-full broke pot
fields.creole: Belly-full bruck pat

fields.english: Bembah, look at me, I'm watching you
fields.creole: Bembah rubembah you peep me, me sa watch you

fields.english: It's better to watch a box full of cockroaches than a girl.
fields.creole: Bettah fo' watch wan ban'box full cockroach dan wan gal

fields.english: It's better to paddle your own canoe than to wait for your friend to paddle it for you.
fields.creole: Bettah paddle you' own canoe dan wait fo' you matty paddle am fo' you

fields.english: The bird is angry with the tree, where will he stand up?
fields.creole: Bi'd bex wid tree, weh he go 'tan' up?

fields.english: The bird that flies too high must pass its nest.
fields.creole: Bi'd fly too high mus' pass he nes'

fields.english: A big house has a big story
fields.creole: Big house ha' big 'tory

fields.english: The big liver burst his belly
fields.creole: Big libah a-buss he belly

fields.english: A big man doesn't run for nothing.
fields.creole: Big man no a-run fo' not'in'

fields.english: Big story about the dog
fields.creole: Big 'tory choke daag

fields.english: Big-eyed, fat spider.
fields.creole: Big yeye choke nancy cat

fields.english: Big eyes make the man pick up the shovel quickly
fields.creole: Big yeye mek niggah pick shovel 'tick

fields.english: Bill, the bird, trusted himself to swallow the seed of the palm tree.
fields.creole: Bill bi'd trus' hese'f mek he swalla tooroo seed

fields.english: Black man's master is the worst kind of master
fields.creole: Black man massa de wossis kin' ob massa

fields.english: Black man steals, he steals a small amount; white man steals, he steals the entire property
fields.creole: Black man tief, he tief half-a-bitt; bacra tief, he tief whole estate

fields.english: Blind eye country, one eye man is the governor.
fields.creole: Blin' yeye country, one yeye man a-gubnah

fields.english: Blind-eyed man can't carry news
fields.creole: Blin' yeye man can't carry news

fields.english: Blind eye man knows his mouth.
fields.creole: Blin' yeye man know he doo' mout.'

fields.english: Blind eye man not a looking glass
fields.creole: Blin' yeye man na wan' lookin' glass

fields.english: Blind eye man never left his walking stick.
fields.creole: Blin' yeye man nebbah lef' he walking 'tick

fields.english: The boy and the foreman can't court in one house.
fields.creole: Boy an' bass can't cou'tin' a-wan house

fields.english: The boastful story doesn't make sense.
fields.creole: Briggah 'tory no lock a-gooby

fields.english: The boastful person has nothing inside
fields.creole: Briggah tongue hab empty inside

fields.english: The broom is not absent from anybody's house.
fields.creole: Broom na absen' a-nobody house

fields.english: The aboriginal Indian has time, he made a fancy wicker basket.
fields.creole: Buck gat time, he mek pegall

fields.english: The aboriginal Indian is enjoying himself, the town is burning.
fields.creole: Buck a-plesha, Buck town a-bu'n

fields.english: The bull is loose in the pasture, so be careful walking near it.
fields.creole: Bull loose a-pasture, man no bound fo' walk close am

fields.english: The old bull, he smeared his tail.
fields.creole: Bull ol,' he smear he tail

fields.english: The bush is burning behind the tiger, and the tiger doesn't smell the smoke.
fields.creole: Bush bu'n behin' tigah, an' tigah no smell smoke

fields.english: The bush has ears
fields.creole: Bush gat yase

fields.english: Buy your food according to your money.
fields.creole: Buy you' nyam, nyam accordin' to you money

fields.english: The ugly bird eats good corn
fields.creole: Caba ca-ba fowl nyam good co'n

fields.english: The calabash is floating in the trench, but it can't float in the river.
fields.creole: Calabash a-float a-trench, but can't float a-ribah,

fields.english: The calabash is a poor man's finger basin.
fields.creole: Calabash a poo-man fingah basin

fields.english: The calabash is green on the outside, but its belly is white.
fields.creole: Calabash outside green, but he belly white

fields.english: The boa constrictor looks good if ants are in front of him before he lies down.
fields.creole: Camoodi does look good if ants deh befo' he lie down

fields.english: Can't break Penitent to make Rumfelt good.
fields.creole: Can't bruck Penitent fo' mek Rumfelt good

fields.english: Can't help but do it on purpose
fields.creole: Can't help" no do fo' purpose

fields.english: You can't fatten a cow for another butcher.
fields.creole: Can't fatten cow fo' nadda butcher

fields.english: Can't stop the river from running.
fields.creole: Can't tap de ribah from runnin'

fields.english: Can't take your dry eye to roast my corn.
fields.creole: Can't tek you dry eye fo' roas' me co'n

fields.english: The captain of a man-of-war turned into a cook on a Guinea ship.
fields.creole: Cap'n a-man-o-war tu'n cook a-Guinea ship

fields.english: Captain Trust has died, bad pay has killed him.
fields.creole: Cap'n Trus' gone dead, bad pay a-kill am

fields.english: Captain Trust has gone home.
fields.creole: Cap'n Trus' gone home

fields.english: The carrion crow eats cow, but cow can't eat carrion crow.
fields.creole: Carrin crow a-nyam cow, cow can't nyam carrin crow

fields.english: The carrion crow says, "The mercy of the Lord is not on the tree."
fields.creole: Carrin crow say, "De mercy ob de Laad no deh 'pon tree

fields.english: The carrion crow says, "One God is above, he never eats grass."
fields.creole: Carrin crow say, "Wan Gaad deh a-tap, he nebbah nyam grass

fields.english: The bird follows the carrion crow, he sleeps by the fire.
fields.creole: Carrow falla carrincrow, he sleep a-fiah side

fields.english: Cassava and okra can't make good soup.
fields.creole: Cassada an' ochro can't mek good soup

fields.english: The cassava is not ripe, do not scratch its bottom.
fields.creole: Cassada no ripe, no 'cratch he battam

fields.english: The cat chased the rat, but he stole his master's pork.
fields.creole: Cat a-dribe rat, but he tief he massa po'k

fields.english: The cat is playing with the bone, the dog wants it.
fields.creole: Cat a-play wid bone, daag want am

fields.english: The cat's foot is soft, but he scratches for real.
fields.creole: Cat foot saf', but he 'cratch fo' true

fields.english: There are no cats, rats have taken over
fields.creole: Cat no deh, ratta tek over

fields.english: Deceitful people always have full control.
fields.creole: 'Ceitful lib a-han'-fu11 doo'

fields.english: A chance blow knocked down the devil himself
fields.creole: Chance blow knack down de debil se'f

fields.english: Exchange for exchange
fields.creole: Changee fo' changee

fields.english: Look at him, boy, you see him win.
fields.creole: Chat am, boy, you sa win am

fields.english: Cheap things make everyone buy
fields.creole: Cheap t'ing mek all man buy

fields.english: The chicken-hawk says he can't catch the mother, so he takes the child.
fields.creole: Chicken-hawk say, he can't get mamma, he tek picknie

fields.english: The chicken-hawk says he lives by his skill, while the carrion crow lives by the grace of God.
fields.creole: Chicken-hawk say, he lib by he skill; carrin-crow, by de grace ob God

fields.english: The chicken hawk never builds its nest with a ground dove.
fields.creole: Chicken hawk nebba buil' he nes' wid ground dove

fields.english: Stupid man buy rum, goat drink it, but sheep get drunk
fields.creole: Chupit haag buy he rum, goat drink am, but sheep get drunk

fields.english: The foolish man gave away his spoon and ate with his hand.
fields.creole: Chupit man gie 'way he 'poon, an' eat wid 'e han.'

fields.english: The foolish man went to close his friend's door, and left his own open.
fields.creole: Chupit man go shut he matty kokah, an' lef' he own open

fields.english: The foolish man spilled water on his lap two times.
fields.creole: Chupit man mek watah car''way he lap two time

fields.english: The foolish man melted lead on a sardine can.
fields.creole: Chupit man melt lead a-sardine pat

fields.english: Foolish man ran a race with a horse
fields.creole: Chupit man run race wid hass

fields.english: A foolish man works and saves his money; when he dies, a wise man spends it.
fields.creole: Chupit man wo'k, put he money; when he dead, sense man spen' am

fields.english: A stupid man wrote it, a smart man can't read it.
fields.creole: Chupit man write am, sense man can't read am

fields.english: The leper told the governor to show himself.
fields.creole: Claninclo a-gubnah tell daag show hese'f

fields.english: It's easy to get dirty, but hard to wash.
fields.creole: Clat' easy fo' dutty, but haad fo' was'

fields.english: When the rooster crows, it's a sign that a stranger is coming.
fields.creole: Cock crow a-doo' mout', a sign 'tranger a-come

fields.english: The rooster is scratching, the hen is scratching, the children are scratching, they can't sleep hungry.
fields.creole: Cock grabble, hen grabble, picknie grabble, dem can't sleep hungry

fields.english: The cockroach is so drunk, he can't even walk straight.
fields.creole: Cockroach ebba so drunk, he no walk a-fowl house

fields.english: The cockroach says he has feet to run, but the centipede catches him.
fields.creole: Cockroach say he gat foot fo' run, but sentapee catch am

fields.english: The coconut tree branch never fights against the strong wind.
fields.creole: Coc'nut tree branch nebba fight high win'

fields.english:
"Come, come," is a sweet, fish
Text: "Kom, kom," is a swiit, fish
fields.creole: Come, come," is a sweet, fish

fields.english: Corn flour is more than water
fields.creole: Co'n flour mo' dan watah

fields.english: The Congo eel is still a fish.
fields.creole: Congo eel still is a fish

fields.english: Congo mulatto, who is going to marry you?
fields.creole: Congo mulatto, who sa marry you?

fields.english: Congo sir, live a hand-full too.
fields.creole: Congo sah lib a-han'-full doo

fields.english: Consequential makes crab have no head.
fields.creole: Consequential mek crab hab no head

fields.english: A contented man eats pepper and salt for breakfast.
fields.creole: Contented man eat peppah an' sal' fo' breakfast

fields.english: Coo-coo won't choke you if you don't drink okra soup.
fields.creole: Coo-coo no choke you no drink ochro soup

fields.english: The Indian man has a clean dam for dirty, he sits down and says he is very sorry.
fields.creole: Coolie gat clean dam fo' dutty, he si' down say he a-prap sorrow

fields.english: Indian laborers wear loincloths, not pants, that is their traditional clothing.
fields.creole: Coolie wear baba, na wandah, da he country fashion

fields.english: The cottee-cotte-soup has all its steam at the bottom.
fields.creole: Cottee-cotte-soup hab all he 'team a-battam

fields.english: One country killing another country
fields.creole: Country kill country

fields.english: The country may change, but my heart does not change.
fields.creole: Country tu'n, but me haat no tu'n

fields.english: A cowardly person keeps the entire bone
fields.creole: Coward man keep whole bone

fields.english: The cow is dead, he left the story to give to his kin.
fields.creole: Cow dead, he lef' 'tory gie he 'kin

fields.english: The cow died, his master cried; the carrion crow laughed.
fields.creole: Cow dead, he massa cry; carrin crow laugh

fields.english: The cow is in the pasture, he doesn't remember the butcher and the dog until he sees them.
fields.creole: Cow deh a-pastah, he no membah butchah an' daag teh he see am

fields.english: The cow never told the pastor "Goodbye"
fields.creole: Cow nebbah tell pastah "Goo' bye

fields.english: The cow doesn't eat pepper, but it's in the manure.
fields.creole: Cow no eat peppah, but he down a-manure am

fields.english: The cow doesn't have a tail, God Almighty brushed away the flies.
fields.creole: Cow no hab tail, Gaad A'mighty brush fly

fields.english: The cow doesn't realize it has lost its tail until the fly season.
fields.creole: Cow no know he loss 'e tail teh cow-fly season

fields.english: The cow says that the dam is dirty, but he is dirty himself.
fields.creole: Cow say he dutty 'pon dam, but he dutty he own tail

fields.english: The cow's tail never passes its head.
fields.creole: Cow tail nebba pass he head

fields.english: The greedy dog ate all the corn and husk.
fields.creole: Craben daag a-loss co'n an' husk

fields.english: A crab knows its hole, but a toad doesn't know its hole.
fields.creole: Crab know he 'ole, but crapaud na know he 'ole

fields.english: The crab doesn't walk, so he doesn't get fat; if he walks too much, he gets stepped on.
fields.creole: Crab no walk he no get fat; he walk too much, he get a-pat

fields.english: Clean your own calabash before you clean your neighbor's.
fields.creole: 'Crape you own calabash, befo' you 'crape you matty own

fields.english: The frog didn't know that the water was too hot until it fell on his back.
fields.creole: Crapaud no bin sabby too watah teh hot watah fall a-he back

fields.english: A crazy man knows the governor
fields.creole: Crazy man know gubnah

fields.english: The crow is always ready for a funeral, that's why he wears his burial suit.
fields.creole: Crow always ready fo' funeral mek he wear he berrin' suit

fields.english: The crying child never has anything right
fields.creole: Cry-cry picknie nehba hab right

fields.english: Cuffy! Come and see fish in muddy water.
fields.creole: Cuffy! come see fish a-muddy watah

fields.english: Cursing never bore a hole in me.
fields.creole: Cuss-cuss nebba bore hole a-me 'kin

fields.english: Cut the cow's horn, but don't cut its heart.
fields.creole: Cut cow handle, you no cut he haat

fields.english: Cut your eye and kill the dog.
fields.creole: Cut yeye na a-kill daag

fields.english: The dog bites his neighbor, but he doesn't bite himself.
fields.creole: Daag a-bite he matty, but he no a-bite hese'f

fields.english: The dog bites his tail, but he doesn't bark at himself.
fields.creole: Daag a-bite he tail, but he na a-bark 'pon hese'f

fields.english: The dog bites the master, but the master doesn't bite the dog.
fields.creole: Daag a-bite massa, but massa na a-bite daag

fields.english: The dog always lies down in the same spot.
fields.creole: Daag always lie down da place bone a-'tir

fields.english: A dog and a cat can't eat from the same plate.
fields.creole: Dang an' cat can't eat a-wan plate

fields.english: The dog is running for his character, running for his life.
fields.creole: Daag a-run fo' he charatah, haag a-run fo' he life

fields.english: The dog is there, "Mr. Dog"; the dog is not there, no more "Dog"
fields.creole: Daag deh, "Mr. Daag"; daag no deh, no mo' "Daag

fields.english: The dog drinks water quickly for you, but for us not for you.
fields.creole: Daag drink watah chakoo chakoo fi you a-fi you, but fi awe no fi you

fields.english: The dog's foot is broken, he knows his master's door is open.
fields.creole: Daag foot-bruck, he know he massa doo' mout.'

fields.english: The dog has money to buy butter to roast a fire.
fields.creole: Daag gat money buy buttah roas' a-fiah

fields.english: The dog has money, he buys cheese.
fields.creole: Daag gat money, he buy cheese

fields.english: A dog has four feet, but can't walk four roads at once.
fields.creole: Daag hab four foot, but can't walk four road wan time

fields.english: The dog has too much master, he's starving.
fields.creole: Daag hab too much massa him 'tarve

fields.english: The dog lapped water and said "For you, that's for you."
fields.creole: Daag lap watah say " Fo' you da fo' you

fields.english: The dog is skinny but his head is big.
fields.creole: Daag magah he head big

fields.english: Dogs do not eat dogs
fields.creole: Daag no nyam daag

fields.english: The dog said he will keep his dream in his belly because he doesn't know how to talk.
fields.creole: Daag say he sa keep he dream a-he belly 'cause he no know fo' talk

fields.english: The dog set a trap to catch a hare, he fastened himself there.
fields.creole: Daag set trap fo' ketch accouri, he fasten dey hese'f

fields.english: The dog shook his head and said, "He saw how the world is going around."
fields.creole: Daag shub he head a-salmon pat, he sa see how de world a-go roun'

fields.english: The dog stepped on his foot and he gave the tiger a saucy look.
fields.creole: Daag trus' he foot mek he gie tigah saucy

fields.english: The dog that barks a lot usually runs away when it's time to bite.
fields.creole: Daag wah a-bark plenty a-run 'way time fo' bite

fields.english: The dog that brings a bone, carry it.
fields.creole: Daag wah a-bring a bone sa, carry am

fields.english: The dog that ate what his friend left, never gets sick.
fields.creole: Daag wah a-eat wha' he matty lef' nebba 'trang

fields.english: A dog that is used to suck eggs can't live (leave) off
fields.creole: Daag wah use fo' suck egg can't lib (leave) off

fields.english: The dog walks on a dead lion.
fields.creole: Daag walk 'pon dead lion

fields.english: The dog wants to see the bonfire, he throws grass on the fire coal.
fields.creole: Daag wan' fo' see banfiah, he t'row grass 'pon fiah coal

fields.english: The foolish man is wearing a ring in his nose.
fields.creole: Da chupit man wear ring a-he nose

fields.english: The greedy person is always eating a lot.
fields.creole: Da craben always a-eat a-pat

fields.english: The doctor doesn't know where it hurts you until you tell him
fields.creole: Dactah na a-know weh a hu't you teh you tell am

fields.english: The doctor's medicine is always good.
fields.creole: Dactah physic always good

fields.english: The picky dog eats dirty pudding.
fields.creole: Dainty daag nyam dutty puddin'

fields.english: The lazy donkey can't carry his own oats.
fields.creole: Da lazy jackass can't carry he own oats

fields.english: The rice has motion in the pot, but it doesn't have a plate.
fields.creole: Da motion wah rice got a-pot, he no got a-plate

fields.english: The mouth man took to courting a woman to put her in his house, it's not the same mouth he took to put her in the door.
fields.creole: Da mout' man tek fo cou'tin ooman fo' put am a-he house, a na da same mout' he a-tek fo' put am a-doo'

fields.english: The place has meat, safely, safely, the jackass has meat.
fields.creole: Da-place hass meet, safly safly jackass sa meet

fields.english: Where there is molasses, you are sure to see blue flies.
fields.creole: Da place you see molasses, you sure fo' see blue fly

fields.english: The place where we live, it's standing very well.
fields.creole: Da place weh 1ibin', deh 'tan' foo good

fields.english: The place where the thorn pricked your foot, go back there and take it out.
fields.creole: Da place weh pimplah bore you foot, go back deh go tek am out

fields.english: The dark night has no governor.
fields.creole: Dark night hab no gubnah

fields.english: The dark night made the flies boil the soup.
fields.creole: Dark night mek fly boil a-soup

fields.english: The thing that sweetens the goat is what kills it.
fields.creole: Da t'ing wah sweeten goat, a da a-kill am

fields.english: That's something you see in the daytime, don't use a torch at night to look at it.
fields.creole: Da somet'ing you a-see a-day time, no tek fiah 'tick a-night fo' look am

fields.english: A dead chicken brings money.
fields.creole: Dead chicken bring dallah

fields.english: There is trouble ahead, he doesn't care for his boss.
fields.creole: Dead deh a-hass eye, he no ca' fo' he massa

fields.english: Death is not finished, crying is not finished
fields.creole: Dead no done, cry no done

fields.english: It seems like he has forgotten.
fields.creole: Dead seem fo' fo'get he

fields.english: The devil tempted, but he didn't force
fields.creole: Debil a-tempt, but he no a-fo'ce

fields.english: The devil doesn't see his own faults.
fields.creole: Debil bad no see he paint am black

fields.english: The long prayer got an amen.
fields.creole: De langes' pray got a amen

fields.english: The same hammer that drives nails can take them out.
fields.creole: De same hammah wah dribe nail sa tek am out

fields.english: Dig a hole to fill a hole
fields.creole: Dig a hole fo' full a hole

fields.english: This is telling the other, until the story comes.
fields.creole: Dis a-tell tarra, tara narra, till 'tory come

fields.english: This time is not like before.
fields.creole: Dis time no like befo' time

fields.english: One for one, don't practice witchcraft.
fields.creole: Do fo' do no obeah

fields.english: Don't worry, keep a big house.
fields.creole: Don' ca'e," keep big house

fields.english: Don't let your tail pass your head.
fields.creole: Don' mek you tail pass you head

fields.english: Don't judge my story by your own standards and perspective.
fields.creole: Don' weigh me 'tory by you own 'cale an' weight

fields.english: Don't do that, don't love like that.
fields.creole: Do so no lobe so

fields.english: Downfall is not for one man.
fields.creole: Downfall no fo' wan man

fields.english: The children are playing in the yard.
fields.creole: Dribah na deh creole a-play

fields.english: Drive all the cows, the black one must run
fields.creole: Dribe yalla cow, black wan mus' run

fields.english: Drink rum in your mouth, it will fly to your head.
fields.creole: Drink rum a-you mout', he sa f1y a-you head

fields.english: A drunk man never knows he is drunk.
fields.creole: Drunk man nebba know he drunk

fields.english: The drunk man told the lantern post, "excuse me, sir"
fields.creole: Drunk man tell lantern pos', "ask paadon, sah

fields.english: Dry wood is burning and green wood is burning too.
fields.creole: Dry wood a-bu'n an' green wood a-bu'n too

fields.english: The duck has water to wash itself, the fowl wants it to drink.
fields.creole: Duck hab watah fo' was' he 'kin, fowl want am fo' drink

fields.english: Dirty water can put out fire
fields.creole: Dutty watah can out fiah

fields.english: Dirty water cools copper
fields.creole: Dutty watah cool cappah

fields.english: Ear doesn't hear, eyes see
fields.creole: Ear no yery, yeye sa see

fields.english: Easy come, easy go
fields.creole: Easy get easy spen'

fields.english: Don't squeeze too hard, it might hurt.
fields.creole: Easy squeeze no feel hurt

fields.english: Not every full belly is a satisfied one.
fields.creole: Ebery belly-full no a pat full

fields.english: Everybody feels their own pain.
fields.creole: Eberybody feel he own pain

fields.english: Every captain is in charge of his own boat.
fields.creole: Ebery cap'n bass he own boat

fields.english: Every cock crows at its own door, mouth.
fields.creole: Ebery cock crow a-he own doo, mout'

fields.english: Every cow cries for its own calf.
fields.creole: Ebery cow cry fo' he own calf

fields.english: Every dog bites the master's door.
fields.creole: Ebery daag a-bite da-he massa doo'

fields.english: Every dog has his day
fields.creole: Ebery daag ha' he day

fields.english: Every donkey thinks he's good enough to rank with the governor's horse.
fields.creole: Ebery donkey t'ink hese'f good fo' rank wid gubnah hass

fields.english: Every day the bucket goes to the well, one day its bottom will be left behind.
fields.creole: Ebery day bucket go a-well, wan day he battam sa lef'

fields.english: Every day the devil helps the thief; one day God must help the watchman.
fields.creole: Ebery day debil help tief; wan day God mus' help watchman

fields.english: Every day is a fishing day, but not every day is a catching day.
fields.creole: Ebery day fishin' day, but ebery day no ketchin' day

fields.english: Every day you are challenging your friend, one day you will get your punishment.
fields.creole: Ebery day you a-challenge you matty, wan day you sa get you' poison

fields.english: Every day you are playing in dirty water, one day it will make you sick.
fields.creole: Ebery day you a-play a-dutty watah, wan day he go nassy you' 'kin

fields.english: Every field must have grass.
fields.creole: Ebery fiel' mus' get grass

fields.english: Every fool has their own sense.
fields.creole: Ebery fool got he own sense

fields.english: Every blade of grass is a man at night.
fields.creole: Ebery grass is a man a-night time

fields.english: Every hole of the net caught June fish.
fields.creole: Ebery haul ob de net no ketch June fish

fields.english: Every greeting is a greeting
fields.creole: Ebery howdee na howdee

fields.english: Every blackbird thinks his own chick is white.
fields.creole: Ebery John crow t'ink he own picknie white

fields.english: Every kind of teeth doesn't laugh.
fields.creole: Ebery 'kin teet' no laugh

fields.english: Every long prayer must have an amen
fields.creole: Ebery lang prayer mus' gat amen

fields.english: Every lawyer likes a fat chicken
fields.creole: Ebery lawyer like fat fowl

fields.english: Every man knows where his own house is leaking.
fields.creole: Ebery man know weh he own house a-leak

fields.english: Every man is the master of his own house.
fields.creole: Ebery man massa fo' he own house

fields.english: Every man to his own class
fields.creole: Ebery man to he own class

fields.english: Every man works for money, but not every man can keep it.
fields.creole: Ebery man wo'k fo' money, but no ebery man can keep am

fields.english: Every makeup face doesn't cry.
fields.creole: Ebery mek up face na cry

fields.english: Every rope has two ends
fields.creole: Ebery rope gat two en'

fields.english: Every shaky hand is not a shaky hand
fields.creole: Ebery shake han' no shake han'

fields.english: Every closed eye is not asleep
fields.creole: Ebery shut eye na a-sleep

fields.english: Everywhere you look there is water, but not every water source is clean.
fields.creole: Eberysore yeye a watah yeye, but na ebery watah yeye a sore yeye

fields.english: Every thief knows his own trade.
fields.creole: Ebery tief man know he own trade

fields.english: Every time the fowl drinks water, he lifts his head up and says "Thank God"
fields.creole: Ebery time fowl drink watah, he hise he head a-tap an'say "Teng Gaad

fields.english: Every time it rains, the carrion crow swears he will build a house; when the sun comes out, he forgets.
fields.creole: Ebery time rain fall clarinclo swear he sa buil' house; when sun come out, he fo'get

fields.english: Every tub stands on its own bottom.
fields.creole: Ebery tub'tan' pon he own battam

fields.english: Every water is for drinking, but not every story is for telling.
fields.creole: Ebery watah fo' drink, but ebery 'tory no fo' tell

fields.english: Everywhere you turn, there are plenty of friends.
fields.creole: Ebery way you tu'n primo matty deh

fields.english: Every wind is a full sail.
fields.creole: Ebery win' na a-full sail

fields.english: The elephant knows that the backbone is big, that's why he looks for a way to swallow the coconut.
fields.creole: Elephant sabby say be back-bone big da mek so he look fo' swalla coc'nut

fields.english: The elephant says with all his size, he doesn't want any trouble with man.
fields.creole: Elephant say wid all he big, he no wan' 'tory wid man

fields.english: The elephant's ears are big, but he doesn't listen to his own story.
fields.creole: Elephant yase big, but he no a-yeddy he own 'tory

fields.english: An empty bag cannot stand up.
fields.creole: Empty bag can't 'tan' up

fields.english: I can see his friend, but can't see himself
fields.creole: Eye can see he matty, but can't see hese'f

fields.english: Father works, children spend
fields.creole: Faada wo'k picknie spen'

fields.english: Family quarrels do not cut deep.
fields.creole: Family cutlish na cut deep

fields.english: Fat chicken, pick it clean
fields.creole: Fat fowl, pick am clean

fields.english: Farther up, make okra dry on the tree.
fields.creole: Far-a-pa mek ochro dry a-tree

fields.english: Today we feast, tomorrow we starve
fields.creole: Feast to-day, famine to-morrow

fields.english: Fire and powder don't mix
fields.creole: Fiah an' powdah no matty

fields.english: Fire is burning at the back of the house, he says "Cool breeze"
fields.creole: Fiah deh a-money tail he say "Cool breeze

fields.english: There is no fire, so the pot can't boil.
fields.creole: Fiah no deh, pat can't boil

fields.english: Finger never says "Look here," but "Look over there"
fields.creole: Fingah nebba say "Look yah," but "Look yandah

fields.english: The fish is playing in the sea, he doesn't know that the water is boiling for him.
fields.creole: Fish a-play a-sea, he no sabby watah a-bile fo' am

fields.english: A fisherman never says he owns fish, I think.
fields.creole: Fishaman nebba say he own fish 'tink

fields.english: The fish is sleeping, his friend is cutting his tail.
fields.creole: Fish a-sleep, he matty a-cut he tail

fields.english: Flea bite, don't you scratch?
fields.creole: Flea bite, you no 'cratch?

fields.english: The fly says you're foolish, he doesn't know the spider near.
fields.creole: Fly say ya pledja, he na' know spidah neah

fields.english: Fly sat down and shook his foot, then said "Story before, story behind"
fields.creole: Fly si' down an' shake he foot, den say "'Tory befo', 'tory behin'

fields.english: Follow the pattern and never get into trouble.
fields.creole: Follow pattern nebba out ob trouble

fields.english: Foo-foo is not for you, don't cut it deeply.
fields.creole: Foo-foo na fo' you, na cut am deep

fields.english: For me it's for me, but for you it's not for me
fields.creole: Fo' me a-fo' me, but f'awe na fo' me

fields.english: A foolish man is learning from a wise man.
fields.creole: Foolish man a-learn sense man sense

fields.english: The foolish man is talking, but he is not listening.
fields.creole: Foolish man a-talk, but na a-listen

fields.english: A foolish man kills a cow, a wise man eats it.
fields.creole: Foolish man kill cow, sense man eat am

fields.english: A foolish man took a hit to hammer a nail into a plank.
fields.creole: Foolish man tek cuff fo' knack nail a-plank

fields.english: I ate my food and I didn't give you any.
fields.creole: Food me eat me na gie you

fields.english: For a second time, I can't do better.
fields.creole: Fo' secka fo' secka me can't do bettah

fields.english: A chicken may sit on duck eggs, but it doesn't do what a duck does.
fields.creole: Fowl a-hatch duck, but he no a-do wha' duck a-do

fields.english: The chicken and duck don't want to, but they sleep in the same pen.
fields.creole: Fowl an' duck no wan, but dem sleep a-wan pen

fields.english: The rooster may be foolish, but that doesn't make him a villain.
fields.creole: Fowl-cock a fool, but da na mek am villain

fields.english: The chicken is cooking in the country; the man is not turning.
fields.creole: Fowl-cook country tu'n; man na tu'n

fields.english: The rooster heard the war coming, so he climbed on top of the tree and said he's a lighthouse keeper.
fields.creole: Fowl-cook hear war a-come he climb a-tap tree say he a light-house keepah

fields.english: The chicken eats and wipes its mouth on the ground; the dog licks the hand that feeds it.
fields.creole: Fowl eat an' wipe he mout' a-groun'; daag a-lick de han' wah feed am

fields.english: The fowl's eye passed the corn, he's angry.
fields.creole: Fowl eye pass co'n, he bad

fields.english: The fowl is dancing, the cockroach has no business being there.
fields.creole: Fowl gie dance, cockroach no bu'iness deh

fields.english: The chicken is happy, but the hawk caught it.
fields.creole: Fowl merry, hawk ketch am

fields.english: The fowl didn't miss its egg until it wanted to sit on it.
fields.creole: Fowl no a-miss he egg teh he wan' fo' set

fields.english: The bird says he's going to sleep soon, because he doesn't want any trouble to meet him.
fields.creole: Fowl say he a-sleep soon, 'cause he no wan' trouble fo' meet am

fields.english: The fowl saw the matapee and said it's a boa constrictor.
fields.creole: Fowl see matapee he say a camoodi

fields.english: The fowl saw the wood ants' nest, so it sharpened its beak.
fields.creole: Fowl see wood ants' nes', he sharpen he toe

fields.english: A foul swears to hatch a rotten egg, a rotten egg swears to spoil its own kind.
fields.creole: Fowl swaer fo' hatch rotten egg, rotten egg swear fo' pile he 'kin'

fields.english: A fowl may swear for its egg, but it doesn't swear for its chick.
fields.creole: Fowl swear fo' him hegg, he no swear fo' him picknie

fields.english: The fowl stepped on her chicken, but he didn't step hard.
fields.creole: Fowl tread 'pon he chicken, but he no tread haad

fields.english: For you, it's for you, for me, it's for me
fields.creole: Fo' you a-fo you, fo' me a-fo' me

fields.english: For you and for us, it's not one
fields.creole: Fo' you an' fo' awe na wan

fields.english: A person who is full does not understand the suffering of a hungry person.
fields.creole: Full belly man na know wha' hungry belly a-suffer

fields.english: First jump and then jump
fields.creole: Fus' jump na jump

fields.english: First laugh isn't the ending
fields.creole: Fus' laugh ain't de ending

fields.english: Girl, I love you because you have long black hair.
fields.creole: Gal me lobe you 'cause you got lotan hair

fields.english: The girl didn't hear the mother's story, so she's confused (find her mistake.)
fields.creole: Gal wah no yery mamma 'tory sa larikary (find her mistake.)

fields.english: The gambler is walking with his money in his hand.
fields.creole: Gamble man a-walk wid he libba a-he han'

fields.english: The dog is playing with the lizard, he can't play with the anteater.
fields.creole: Game wah daag a-play with sal'pentah, he can't play am wid ants-eater

fields.english: Get it for nothing, eat it for gluttony.
fields.creole: Get am fo' not'in' eat am fo' glutton

fields.english: The bread is not in the man's eyes, but he filled his mouth.
fields.creole: Gill bread na a-full man yeye, but he full he mout'

fields.english: The child is eating a little bit of bread with his mouth.
fields.creole: Gill bread na ha tear li'l creole mout'

fields.english: The goat is happy, jumping and playing around.
fields.creole: Goat a-merry, a-pung he a-go

fields.english: Goats and sheep cannot stay in the same pen.
fields.creole: Goat an' sheep can't 'tan' a-wan pen

fields.english: The goat is happy, he forgot the knife on the table.
fields.creole: Goat a-plesha, he fo'get knife a-table

fields.english: The goat is dead, but he can still make a sound
fields.creole: Goat dead, but he 'kin sa mek down

fields.english: The goat is on the riverbank, he gave the tiger a saucy look.
fields.creole: Goat deh obah ribah, he gie tigah saucy

fields.english: His foot is broken, but his mouth is not broken.
fields.creole: Gaot foot bruck, but he mout' no bruck

fields.english: The goat frightens the tiger, the eye frightens the eye.
fields.creole: Goat friken tigah, yeye friken yeye

fields.english: Goat head and sheep head are not the same
fields.creole: Goat head an' sheep head na wan

fields.english: The goat knows he can jump, so he climbs to high places.
fields.creole: Goat know he can jump da mek he does climb high place

fields.english: The goat taught his child to climb a high place, then turned back and told him that he would break his neck if he climbed there.
fields.creole: Goat la'n he picknie fo' climb a high place, den tu'n back tell am say he go bruck he nek if he climb deh

fields.english: The goat is sitting down on a rope grazing, while the wild animal's mother is cooking sweet soup.
fields.creole: Goat si' down a rope a-graze, yawarri mamma cook sweet soup

fields.english: Trouble and the sea have no back door
fields.creole: Trouble an' sea no gat no back doo

fields.english: God Almighty never sleeps
fields.creole: God A'mighty nebba sleep

fields.english: God does not like ugly
fields.creole: God no like ugly

fields.english: Gold diggers don't have eyes to see.
fields.creole: Gol' diggah money na gat yeye fo' see

fields.english: A good calabash cannot float in the river.
fields.creole: Good calabash can't float a-ribah

fields.english: Good fowl laid eggs, what do you think of that?
fields.creole: Good fowl 'pile egg, wha' you t'ink a sensa?

fields.english: A good heart makes a person stand tall today.
fields.creole: Good heart mek haag 'tan' so t'day

fields.english: Good living stands like an egg, when it falls you can't pick it up
fields.creole: Good libin' 'tan' like hegg, when he fall you can't pick am up

fields.english: Good men don't last long, but bad men live forever.
fields.creole: Good man no las' lang, but bad man libe fo' true

fields.english: I do good, but I see bad.
fields.creole: Good me do, bad me see

fields.english: A good woman takes the cayman's teeth to make sugar cake.
fields.creole: Good ooman tek cayman teet' mek sugah cake

fields.english: The good gentleman stands like a cock wanting to crow.
fields.creole: Good sahib 'tan' like a cock wan' crow

fields.english: A good thief becomes a good watchman.
fields.creole: Good tief man tu'n good watchman

fields.english: Good words are good, but good deeds are better.
fields.creole: Good word good, good deed bettah

fields.english: The grass is growing, but the horses are starving.
fields.creole: Grass a-grow, but haas a-'tarve

fields.english: The greedy puppy is choking.
fields.creole: Greedy choke puppy

fields.english: A craben man always sleep hungry
fields.creole: Greedy man always sleep hungry

fields.english: The greedy man's eyes are yellow twice.
fields.creole: Greedy man yeye yalla two time

fields.english: Greedy people get angry twice.
fields.creole: Greedy people does bex two time

fields.english: The green lime dropped and left a yellow one.
fields.creole: Green lime drap lef' yalla wan

fields.english: The governor doesn't know what he wants until he's hungry.
fields.creole: Gubnah no know he want till he hungry

fields.english: The guinea pig says he doesn't want a story, that's why he doesn't have a tail.
fields.creole: Guinea pig say he no wan' 'tory, da da mek he no gat tail

fields.english: A gunman cannot stand up to kill all the birds.
fields.creole: Gun man can't 'tan' up fo' kill all bi'd

fields.english: The gun doesn't know its own master.
fields.creole: Gun no know he own massa

fields.english: The gutter is overflowing with water, but a pail must be there to catch it.
fields.creole: Guttah a-run watah, but pail mus' deh fo' ketch am

fields.english: He was born with a tail, but he can live without it.
fields.creole: Haag bo'n wid tail, but he can libe widout am

fields.english: He can't feed himself without eating his children.
fields.creole: Haag can't fat birout he eat he pickin'

fields.english: High head and high tail are not one
fields.creole: Haag head an haag tail na wan

fields.english: There is no doctor
fields.creole: Haag na gat dactah

fields.english: Horses pass by the stable
fields.creole: Haas a-pastah na haas a-stable

fields.english: He lifted something heavy, but the small stick broke his back.
fields.creole: Haas a 'trang somet'ing, but li'l 'tick bruck he back

fields.english: Hass gets credit for his running ability, and the donkey for his kicking one.
fields.creole: Hass get credit fo' he runnin' foot, jackass fo' he kickin wan

fields.english: Have your own is better than being beholden.
fields.creole: Hab you' own bettah dan beholden

fields.english: Hard living makes the driver carry hog meat.
fields.creole: Ha'd libin' mek dribah carry haag meat

fields.english: Hard living makes the laborer and the ibis feed on one another's sorrow
fields.creole: Ha'd libin' mek ploward an' gaulin' a-feed a-wan drain

fields.english: Hard times make the dog eat roasted corn.
fields.creole: Ha'd time mek daag nyam roas' co'n

fields.english: Hard times make the chicken catch fish in the trench.
fields.creole: Ha'd time mek fowl ketch fish a-trench

fields.english: Hard times make a man boil calalu.
fields.creole: Ha'd time mek man bile calalu

fields.english: Hard times make poor men eat leftovers
fields.creole: Ha'd time mek poo' man eat matty

fields.english: Hard times make the poor man smoke tobacco stick
fields.creole: Ha'd time mek smoke man smoke tabacca 'tick

fields.english: Hard to get butter out of a dog's throat
fields.creole: Ha'd to get buttah out ob a daag t'roat

fields.english: They don't know what's ahead
fields.creole: Hair na know wha' deh a-head

fields.english: A small amount of money can't solve a big problem
fields.creole: Half-a-bitt mek trouble joe can't cure

fields.english: Hand the tiger's mouth, you must pull out safely, safely.
fields.creole: Han' deh a-tigah mout', you mus' pull out safly safly

fields.english: I have a handful of company
fields.creole: Han'-full hab company

fields.english: Hand in, hand out
fields.creole: Han' go, han' come

fields.english: Hand made rope, rope tied hand
fields.creole: Han' mek rope, rope tie han'

fields.english: A handsome face girl is not the best kind of girl.
fields.creole: Han'some face gal na de besses kin' a gal

fields.english: Hand wash hand, all too hand clean.
fields.creole: Han' was' han' all too han' clean

fields.english: The harness does not fit the dog and cat.
fields.creole: Harness no a-fit daag an' cat

fields.english: He is carrying his fortune on his back.
fields.creole: He a-carry he fortune on he back

fields.english: He keeps his books so well that even a cockroach can't get to them.
fields.creole: He a-keep book so da cockroach se'f can't get am

fields.english: Hevii kluod, noo rein
fields.creole: Heavy clould, no rain

fields.english: He went through the woods and picked up a crooked stick.
fields.creole: He bin t'rough the woods, an' he pick up a crooked 'tick

fields.english: He speaks inconsistently, saying one thing and then the opposite.
fields.creole: He blow hot an' col' wid de same mout'

fields.english: He has the key to the street.
fields.creole: He gat de key a de street

fields.english: He has a sheep's head ready.
fields.creole: He gat sheep head a-ready

fields.english: He is like a ship without a bottom
fields.creole: He like a ship widout a battam

fields.english: His mouth is as sweet as a pot full of rice.
fields.creole: He mout' sweet like a rice-full pat

fields.english: He is not at the water-cow.
fields.creole: He na deh a-gooby

fields.english: Hang your basket where your hand can reach it.
fields.creole: Heng you' quake weh you' han' can meet am

fields.english: He picked at my teeth to clean my gums.
fields.creole: He pick a-me teet' fo' get a-me gums

fields.english: Harry came to ask Pickle how he is doing.
fields.creole: Herrin' come fo' ask pickle how he situate

fields.english: His tongue has no time on the clock.
fields.creole: He tongue na gat leb na clock

fields.english: Hold the cow before you bargain to sell the beef.
fields.creole: Hol' de cow befo' you bargain fo' sell de beef

fields.english: Hot water burned the cat, when he saw cold water he got scared.
fields.creole: Hot watah bu'n cat, when he see col' watah he friken

fields.english: Houri told Patwa one day we should meet on top of.
fields.creole: Houri tell patwa wan day awe sa meet a-'tap off

fields.english: Hello and thank you, don't break any bones.
fields.creole: Howdee an' tenkee break no bones

fields.english: A hundred dollars can get into a house, and nobody hears it; but when death comes in, there is too much crying.
fields.creole: Hundred dallah get in a house, nobody no yeddy; but dead get in, too much cry

fields.english: A hungry belly makes a man's mouth corner white.
fields.creole: Hungry belly mek man mout' ca'nah white

fields.english: A hungry person doesn't know that soup isn't sweet.
fields.creole: Hungry belly man na know soup na sweet

fields.english: A hungry stomach tells a sweet mouth to "stand aside"
fields.creole: Hungry belly tell sweet mout' " 'Tan' wan side

fields.english: The hungry man caught a Chinese person and ate a snake.
fields.creole: Hungry bode (take hold of) Chinee, he nyam snake

fields.english: Hungry has no master
fields.creole: Hungry gat no massa

fields.english: A hungry man looks for food; when a man is satisfied, he finds fault.
fields.creole: Hungry man look fo' nyam salt ; man satisfy, he fin' fault

fields.english: Hunger makes a man thin
fields.creole: Hungry mek man magah

fields.english: Don't be hungry, don't curse a thief.
fields.creole: Hungry no bode you, no cuss tief man

fields.english: Hurry up and make a bad curry
fields.creole: Hurry hurry mek bad curry

fields.english: If an alligator comes out of the water bottom and tells you "Water mamma's eyes are blind," you must believe it.
fields.creole: If alligittah come out a-watah battam tell you say, "Watah mamma yeye blin'," you mus' belieb am

fields.english: If I tell you the last year's story, tears will run in your eyes.
fields.creole: If a tell you las' yeah 'tory, watah run a-you yeye

fields.english: If bad reputation could kill rats, all the rats would be dead.
fields.creole: If bad name could kill rat, all ratta go dead

fields.english: If the coal pot doesn't have a bottom, the fire can't stay.
fields.creole: If coal pat na gat battam, fiah can't 'tan'

fields.english: If the chicken coop is full, the chickens can't lay rotten eggs.
fields.creole: If fowl house full, fowl can't mek ratten eggs hatch

fields.english: If you're greedy, wait for the hot to cool down.
fields.creole: If greedy wait, hot sa cool

fields.english: If he had a spoon, he would drink soup.
fields.creole: If he bin hab spoon, he sa drink soup

fields.english: If he had spat him out, he couldn't have favored him more.
fields.creole: If he bin spit he out, he couldn't favah he mo'

fields.english: If a donkey could talk, he would say "Oh, poor Job!"
fields.creole: If jackass could a-talk he sa say "Aow, poo' Job!

fields.english: If a man is idle, he tempts the devil.
fields.creole: If man am idle, he temp' de debil

fields.english: If a man milks a cow, he must drink the milk.
fields.creole: If man milk cow, he mus' drink milk

fields.english: If a man doesn't bend his back, he will hit his head against a post.
fields.creole: If man na ben' he back, he go jam he head a-post

fields.english: If a man sits up high and falls, he will break his neck.
fields.creole: If man si' down high an' he fall, he go bruck he neck

fields.english: If I had known, I would always be behind the door
fields.creole: If me bin know always deh behin' de doo

fields.english: If I had known it would be a bad aftermath
fields.creole: If me bin know is a bad after-blow

fields.english: If I had known, I would not have lost the child for the water-mamma.
fields.creole: If me bin know, me loss picknie fo' mamma

fields.english: If my man doesn't beat me, he doesn't love me.
fields.creole: If me man no beat me, he no lobe me

fields.english: If the child doesn't hear "Done," he doesn't hear "Take care"
fields.creole: If picknie no heah "Done," he no heah "Tek ca'

fields.english: If a snake bites you and you see a lizard, you must run.
fields.creole: If snake bite you an' you see lizar', you mus' run

fields.english: If the sun doesn't set, the man won't stop crying.
fields.creole: If sun no done, man no done cry

fields.english: If the stranger had heard what he was saying, he would never have gone to the stranger's house.
fields.creole: If 'tranjah man bin heah wha' he walkin'-'tick say, he nebba go a-'trange man house

fields.english: If the trousers say the master is a thief, you can't doubt it.
fields.creole: If trouses say massa tief, you can't paca (doubt.)

fields.english: If the eyes don't see, the mouth can't talk.
fields.creole: If yeye no see, mout' can't talk

fields.english: If you blow fire with your mouth, ashes will go in your eyes.
fields.creole: If you blow fiah wid you mout', ashes sa go a-you yeye

fields.english: If you can't get turkey, you must be satisfied with vulture.
fields.creole: If you can't get tu'key, you mus' satisfy wid John Crow

fields.english: If you are greedy for your friend's stew, you should buy bread for the cat with the scent.
fields.creole: If you craben fo' you matty chue (stew), you sa buy bread fo' cat wid de scent

fields.english: If you insult John Crow by calling him "Peel head," the guinea hen will be angry.
fields.creole: If you cuss John Crow "Peel head," guinea hen bex

fields.english: If you eat labba and drink creek water, you won't be able to leave the country.
fields.creole: If you eat labba an' drink creek watah, you no able fo lef' de country

fields.english: If your finger gets sore, don't cut it and throw it away.
fields.creole: If you fingah get sore, na cut am t'row 'way

fields.english: If you follow the spring tide, you will see the levee at the dam.
fields.creole: If you fallow spring tide, you sa lef' a-dam

fields.english: If you go to a new place, don't curse where you came from.
fields.creole: If you go a-new place, na cuss weh you come out

fields.english: If you handsome, that's trouble, if you ugly, that's trouble
fields.creole: If you han'some da trouble, if you hugly da trouble

fields.english: If you hurry, your soup will be salty.
fields.creole: If you hurry, you' soup salt

fields.english: If you like dancing, you must like its tail.
fields.creole: If you like dang, you mus' like 'e tail

fields.english: If you don't boast about yourself, your friends won't boast about you.
fields.creole: If you no blow you' own trumpet, you' matty no go blow am fo' you

fields.english: If you don't come back before the spit dries, I know you were playing.
fields.creole: If you no come back befo' spit dry, me know you bin a-play

fields.english: If you don't know the story, ask Jim Crow what happened to John Crow at the high dam yesterday.
fields.creole: If you no know 'tory, ask Jim Crow wha' happen John Crow a-high dam pastah

fields.english: If you don't live in a house, you don't know where it is leaking.
fields.creole: If you no libe a-house, you no know weh he a-leak

fields.english: If you don't meddle with an obeahman, an obeahman will never harm you for money.
fields.creole: If you no meddle wid obeahman, obeahman nebba dun you fo' money

fields.english: If your right eye twitches, you will meet someone good, if your left eye twitches, you will meet someone bad.
fields.creole: If you' right eye dance you sa meet good, if you' lef' eye dance you sa meet bad

fields.english: If you think I'm a fool, put your hand in my mouth.
fields.creole: If you t'ink me a fool, put you' han' a-me mout'

fields.english: If you want the white person to lick his lips, give him plantain water in a calabash.
fields.creole: If you wan' Bacra lickrish (lick his lips) gie am plantain watah a-calabash

fields.english: If you want to eat frog, eat it with egg.
fields.creole: If you wan' fo' eat crapaud, eat am wid egg

fields.english: If you want to hear a story, take a walk outside.
fields.creole: If you wan' no 'tory, tek you' walk abroad

fields.english: If you want to see a monkey cry, stick pepper in its eye.
fields.creole: If you wan' see monkey cry, 'tick peppah in he eye

fields.english: If there is no wick, the lamp cannot burn.
fields.creole: If wick na deh, lamp can't bu'n

fields.english: If the wind doesn't blow, the leaves won't shake.
fields.creole: If win' no blow, leaf no shake

fields.english: If the wind doesn't blow, you won't see the chicken's back
fields.creole: If win no blow, you no see fowl back

fields.english: If your eye jumps, you will cry.
fields.creole: If you yeye jump, you a-go cry

fields.english: I am a saucepan without a cover.
fields.creole: I is saucepan widout a cubbah

fields.english: Is the calabash used to whip obeahman with?
fields.creole: Is calabash whip fo' lick obeahman wid

fields.english: It's the answer that brings the argument
fields.creole: Is de ansah does bring de row

fields.english: It's the luck of a lousy cat that surprises
fields.creole: Is de luck ob a lousy cat does 'tonish

fields.english: It's not the dog that's barking that you must be afraid of.
fields.creole: Is no daag wah a-bark you mus' friken

fields.english: What comes out of your mouth causes trouble, not what is in your belly.
fields.creole: Is wha' come out a-you' mout dá mek trouble, na wha' deh a-you belly

fields.english: A bad tide can always turn.
fields.creole: It is a bad tide which cannot turn

fields.english: It takes a very smart man to catch a hare.
fields.creole: It tek very smart man fo ketch accouri

fields.english: The donkey is in the bush, but the governor is in the house.
fields.creole: Jackass a-bush, but gubnah a-house

fields.english: The donkey drinks rum, the horse gets drunk.
fields.creole: Jackass drink rum, haag get drunk

fields.english: The donkey said "Ah! if it wasn't for the law, there would be too many stories"
fields.creole: Jackass say "Ah! if no bin a law, too much 'tory

fields.english: Jail is not made for dogs, it is made for people.
fields.creole: Jail no mek fo' daag, he mek fo' people

fields.english: The parasitic plant begs and kills
fields.creole: Jango beg, jango kill

fields.english: Jimbo says every man can take care of his own teeth.
fields.creole: Jimbo say Ebery man 'kin he own teet

fields.english: Joseph didn't come to blow fire for everybody; whoever blows fire for him, he blows for them.
fields.creole: Joseph no come fo blow fiah fo' eberybody; who blow fish fo'he, he blow fo' dem

fields.english: The ghost bird cried at the funeral today.
fields.creole: Jumby bi'd halla funeral a-day

fields.english: Ghost calalu cannot make sweet soup
fields.creole: Jumby calalu can't mek sweet soup

fields.english: Ghosts like white cloth
fields.creole: Jumby like white clat'

fields.english: A ghost never sees salt; it swears by sugar.
fields.creole: Jumby nebba see sal'; he swear a-sugah

fields.english: The ghost sends spirits; the spirits send their waiting boy.
fields.creole: Jumby sen' spirit; spirit sen' he waiting boy

fields.english: The tradesman's hand is open on Saturday.
fields.creole: Jump jump trademan han' open 'pon Satu'day

fields.english: Kick and cuff are the same thing
fields.creole: Kick an' cuff same knack

fields.english: Kill the child, give to mother, mother won't eat it; kill mother, give to child, child will eat it.
fields.creole: Kill pieknie, gie mamma, mamma no go eat am; kill mamma gie picknie, picknie go eat am

fields.english: Kiskadee pan accoori
fields.creole: Kiskadee on cowback

fields.english: The kitchen dresser fell down, the skinny dog laughed.
fields.creole: Kitchen dressah fall down, magah daag laugh

fields.english: Knock loudly, the children are scared.
fields.creole: Knock daddy heaby, pieknie sa friken

fields.english: Long discussions make them catch runaway slaves.
fields.creole: Lang discou'se mek dem ketch runaway niggah

fields.english: A long-nosed dog can't blow fire.
fields.creole: Lang nose daag can't blow fiah

fields.english: Long story short, the turtle didn't want to carry his trunk on his back.
fields.creole: Lang 'tory tu'tle no wan' mek he carry he trunk a-he back

fields.english: A learned man walks safely, an unlearned man keeps quiet.
fields.creole: Larnid man walk saf'ly, unlarnid man keep nise

fields.english: Lazy people always have plenty of work.
fields.creole: Lazy man always get 'nough wo'k

fields.english: A lazy man's belly is never full.
fields.creole: Lazy man belly neba sa full

fields.english: The leaf fell in the water, it didn't rot at all.
fields.creole: Leaf fall a-watah, he no rotten wan time

fields.english: Fewer people, fewer dirty dishes
fields.creole: Less company, less dutty plate

fields.english: The snake has no legs.
fields.creole: Lie hab no legs

fields.english: Lie more than a bonfire
fields.creole: Lie mo' dan fiah-bu'n

fields.english: The little boy is staring at the big man's eyes.
fields.creole: Li'l boy a-swell big man yeye

fields.english: The little boy is not climbing the ladder to become a big man.
fields.creole: Li'l boy na a-climb laddah fo' tu'n big man

fields.english: The little finger says "Look over there," the big thumb says "Look here"
fields.creole: Li'l fingah say "Look yandah," bing t'umb say "Look yah

fields.english: A little fun is better than a whole gun
fields.creole: Li'l fun bettah mo' dan whole gun

fields.english: Small garden, but bitter weed
fields.creole: Li'l garden, but bittah weed

fields.english: Small shoe, big shoe, same money; give him the big shoe.
fields.creole: Li'l juta, big juta, same money; gie am big juta

fields.english: The small trench holds big fish.
fields.creole: Li'l trench a-hol' in big fish

fields.english: Limb can't stand without a tree
fields.creole: Limb can't 'tan berout tree

fields.english: Lime never tastes sweet
fields.creole: Lime nebba tas'e sweet

fields.english: The loose goat doesn't feel what the tied goat feels.
fields.creole: Loose-goat na a-feel wha' tie-goat a-feel

fields.english: Luck is better than good looks
fields.creole: Luck mo' bettah dan han'some

fields.english: The macaw asked the parrot if the papaya was ripe, and he said "Yes, yes."
fields.creole: Maccaw ask parrot pajarra ripe, he say "Wan, wan

fields.english: A man who is courting must go away.
fields.creole: Man a-cou'tin' mus' go gay

fields.english: The manager said, "The work for the white person will never be finished."
fields.creole: Manaja cow say, "Bacra wo'k nebba done

fields.english: The manager's horse eats good oats.
fields.creole: Manaja haas nyam good oats

fields.english: The manager takes advantage of the coolie's money, but when the coolie makes a mistake, the manager is the first to criticize him.
fields.creole: Manaja 'tap coolie money, but when coolie mek tadja, a-manaja doo' mout' fus' he a-play

fields.english: Man always looks for what he doesn't want to see.
fields.creole: Man always look fo' wha' he no wan' fo' see

fields.english: The man saw a monkey's neck before he put a chain around his waist.
fields.creole: Man bin see monkey neck befo' he put chain a-he waist

fields.english: The man bought a big-bellied horse, he wants it to cut the grass.
fields.creole: Man buy big belly haas, he wan ha' fo cut grass

fields.english: A man cannot do better; he says "No matter"
fields.creole: Man can't do bettah; he say "No mattah

fields.english: A man can't get a prickly bush rope if he's scared to go and pick it.
fields.creole: Man can't get pamawarri if he friken he pimplah go chook am

fields.english: Man kin run, but man cyaan hide
fields.creole: Man can run, but man can't hide

fields.english: The man cut his timber to haul it.
fields.creole: Man cut he timbah sa haul am

fields.english: The man is dead, and the grass is growing over him.
fields.creole: Man dead, grass grow a-he doo'

fields.english: When a man dies, he dies for real.
fields.creole: Man die, he die fo' true

fields.english: The man finished cooking, the spoon is the last item.
fields.creole: Man done cook, spoon las'

fields.english: The man is drunk, the woman is drunk, who should shut the door?
fields.creole: Man drunk, ooman drunk, who fo' shut de doo'

fields.english: The man has manners, he has a big appetite.
fields.creole: Man gat mannas, he get big foofoo

fields.english: Man has sense, but horses can kick him
fields.creole: Man gat sense, but haas can kick am

fields.english: The man talks too much, he pays his father's debt.
fields.creole: Man gat too much tongue, he pay he daddy debt

fields.english: The man has two houses, but he sleeps hungry.
fields.creole: Man gat two 'ouse, he sleep hungry

fields.english: A man has two eyes, but can't look in two places at once.
fields.creole: Man gat two yeye, but can't look a-two place

fields.english: The man's hand made twine, but the twine turned back to tie his hand.
fields.creole: Man han' a-mek twine, but twine a-tu'n back tie he han'

fields.english: Good morning is better than a bad name in the afternoon.
fields.creole: Ma'nin' bad name bettah mo' 'an aftanoon wan

fields.english: Man hits iron, iron doesn't feel it, iron hits man, man feels it
fields.creole: Man knack iron, iron na a-feel am, iron knack man, man a-feel am

fields.english: A man knows his weakness, so he refuses to challenge a stronger man.
fields.creole: Man know he weak, he refuse 'trang man challenge

fields.english: A man may know your face, but he doesn't know your heart.
fields.creole: Man know you' face, but he na know you' haat

fields.english: Man makes a coffin, but he doesn't want to go there.
fields.creole: Man mek coffin, but he no like a-go deh

fields.english: A man must pay to learn sense.
fields.creole: Man mus' pay fo' larn sense

fields.english: A man must see his wife first before he buys a bed.
fields.creole: Man mus' see he wife fus' befo' he buy bed

fields.english: The man is not a thief until the watchman catches him.
fields.creole: Man na a tief teh watchman ketch am

fields.english: A man doesn't know a little trouble, but he knows too much trouble.
fields.creole: Man na know a trouble, but he know too much a trouble

fields.english: The man doesn't know his mother used to beat him.
fields.creole: Man na know he mamma use teh he dead

fields.english: The man hasn't finished sleeping, he hasn't finished dreaming.
fields.creole: Man no done sleep, he no done dream

fields.english: A man without feet cannot walk.
fields.creole: Man no gat foot, he can't walk

fields.english: The man doesn't like you, he gave you a basket to fetch water.
fields.creole: Man no like you, he gie you basket fo' fetch watah

fields.english: The man doesn't use to drink chocolate, he says he doesn't like it.
fields.creole: Man no nuse (used to) chacklit, he say he no a drink am

fields.english: If a man doesn't talk, news can't spread.
fields.creole: Man no talk, news can't go

fields.english: The man is satisfied, he is content.
fields.creole: Man satisfy, he bore pat

fields.english: The man saw the calabash, but he doesn't know what's inside.
fields.creole: Man see gooby, but he na know wha' deh inside

fields.english: Men talk too much, they pay their father's debt.
fields.creole: Man talk too much, he pay he daddy debt

fields.english: A man who starts before he is ready cannot achieve success.
fields.creole: Man 'tart befo' he ready can't meet good

fields.english: A man can tell his friend's business, but can't tell his own.
fields.creole: Man tell he matty farchin, but can't tell he own

fields.english: The man took a row at the dam, but he didn't care about it, his friend took it for him.
fields.creole: Man tek row a-dam bed he na care am true, he matty care am fo❜ am

fields.english: The man wants to drink rum, but he says he wants to taste brandy to give him an appetite.
fields.creole: Man wan' fo' drink rum, he say yah tas'e brandy fo' gie am appetite

fields.english: A man who has a bottle on the table has plenty of friends.
fields.creole: Man wah got bottle a-table got plenty frien'

fields.english: A man who wants to read a book, it's not hard to find a chapter
fields.creole: Man wah know book, na haad fo' fin' chaptah

fields.english: A man who doesn't have sense stands like a bucket without a bottom.
fields.creole: Man wah na gat sense 'tan' like bucket berout battam

fields.english: A man who wants two wives must have two tongues.
fields.creole: Man wah wan' two wife mus' hab two tongue

fields.english: A man's weapon is his fist, a woman's weapon is her tongue.
fields.creole: Man weapon a-he fist, woman weapon a-he tongue

fields.english: A man with sense wouldn't push his head into a hole.
fields.creole: Man wid sense na go shub he head a-hole

fields.english: Marabuntah can bite, but he can't bite Nancy.
fields.creole: Marabuntah a bite, but he can't bite nancy

fields.english: Married not sure he has a job
fields.creole: Married na sure he gat foot

fields.english: A married man has teeth, he bites like a crab.
fields.creole: Married gat teet', he bite like crab

fields.english: Married people don't have a back door.
fields.creole: Married no got back doo.'

fields.english: Master bull, master cow
fields.creole: Massa bull, massa cow

fields.english: The master is covering himself with a blanket.
fields.creole: Massa niggah a-blanket

fields.english: Matty lost his dog, his neighbor's cornfield is full.
fields.creole: Matty loss he haag, he neighbah co'n-jah full

fields.english: Matty, when you want, you can hide yourself.
fields.creole: Matty wan you wan', you' wan you hide

fields.english: Matty something sweet for your own bitter
fields.creole: Matty somet'ing sweet fo you own bittah

fields.english: I am on fire, I can't stand it anymore.
fields.creole: Me a fiah, me can't 'tan' a-bag

fields.english: I used to be a good dancer, but a chigoe spoiled my foot.
fields.creole: Me bin a good dance man, but chiggah 'pile me foot

fields.english: I bought my calico, I must wear it.
fields.creole: Me buy me calico, me mus' wear am

fields.english: I am already dead tired, I don't want to think.
fields.creole: Me dead haag a'ready, me no ca' fo' 'tink

fields.english: I don't have before, I don't have behind.
fields.creole: Me no gat befo', me no got behin.'

fields.english: I don't have any biscuits in your barrel.
fields.creole: Me no gat no biscuit a-you' barrel

fields.english: I was not born in Ogle back dam.
fields.creole: Me no bo'n a-Ogle back dam

fields.english: I sold my story as I bought it
fields.creole: Me sell me 'tory as me buy am

fields.english: It's easier to stop a river than a woman's tongue.
fields.creole: Mo' easy fo' 'tap ribah dan woman tongue

fields.english: The longer you stand, the more you will bake.
fields.creole: Mo' langah you 'tan', mo' you bake-bake a-col.'

fields.english: The more a man refuses, the more he doesn't save
fields.creole: Mo' man refuse, mo' dinnah save

fields.english: More money, more sin
fields.creole: Mo' money, mo' sin

fields.english: The higher a monkey climbs, the more he shows his tail.
fields.creole: Mo' monkey climb, mo' he show he tail

fields.english: Money is finished, friendship is finished
fields.creole: Money done, frien' done

fields.english: Money doesn't grow on trees.
fields.creole: Money na a-grow 'pon tree

fields.english: Money doesn't make a man
fields.creole: Money na mek man

fields.english: Monkey knows which tree he is climbing on.
fields.creole: Monkey know wha' tree he a-climb 'pon

fields.english: The monkey made his child, he made his mother carry him.
fields.creole: Monkey mek he picknie, he mek ama teh 'e 'pile am

fields.english: The monkey man's child's eyes are very deep.
fields.creole: Monkey men' 'e chil' eye teh 'e go deep deep

fields.english: Monkey father jumps, monkey mother jumps, monkey children must jump.
fields.creole: Monkey papa jump, monkey mamma jump, monkey picknie mus' jump

fields.english: Monkey plays the fiddle for the baboon to run the race.
fields.creole: Monkey play fiddle fo' de baboon run race

fields.english: The monkey put his head on the salmon path, he says the world goes round.
fields.creole: Monkey put he head a-salmon pat, he say de worl' go roun'

fields.english: Monkey says "What's in my belly is mine, what's in my mouth is what Jackman wants"
fields.creole: Monkey say "Wha' deh a-me belly a-me own, wha' deh a-me mout' a jackman want

fields.english: The monkey took trouble in the bush and brought it to the house.
fields.creole: Monkey tek trouble a-bush bring am a-house

fields.english: Monkey turned rich, he rubbed butter on a stick.
fields.creole: Monkey tu'n rich, he roas' buttah 'pon 'tick

fields.english: Moon and stars are beautiful
fields.creole: Moon an' 'tar a-neighbour

fields.english: The moon is running, but the day is catching up with it.
fields.creole: Moon a-run, but day a-ketch am

fields.english: More rain, more rest
fields.creole: Mo' rain, mo' rest

fields.english: Mouth of a freeman, hand of a slave
fields.creole: Mout' a freeman, han' a slabe

fields.english: Mouth made it, somewhere else will pay for it.
fields.creole: Mout' a-mek am, someweh else a-pay fo' am

fields.english: Mouth cut trousers can't fit master
fields.creole: Mout' cut trouses can't fit massa

fields.english:
Mouth eat, back pay
Explanation: This phrase may be a colloquial way of saying that someone has received the consequences of their actions, or that they have gotten what they deserve.
fields.creole: Mout' eat, back pay

fields.english: He was the first one to tell his neighbor that he is black.
fields.creole: Na a fus' wan to tell matty he 'kin black

fields.english: Not all will go to church, to pray.
fields.creole: Na all a-go a-chu'ch house, a-go fo' pray

fields.english: Not all dogs that play with you have good intentions.
fields.creole: Na all daag wah play wid you gat you good a-he min'

fields.english: Not all horses that get first jump win the race.
fields.creole: Na all haas wah get fus' jump a-win race

fields.english: Not all men who are courting are married.
fields.creole: Na all man a-cou'tin' a-married

fields.english: Not everyone wears trousers, man.
fields.creole: Na all man a-wear trouses a man

fields.english: Not all the water that comes out of the eye is crying.
fields.creole: Na all watah wah come out a-yeye a-cry

fields.english: Don't curse the snake before you walk in the bush.
fields.creole: Na cuss snake befo' you walk a-bush

fields.english: Don't curse the water spirit when you go to the creek.
fields.creole: Na cuss watah mamma w'en you go a-creek

fields.english: Don't look at me.
fields.creole: Na cut you' yeye 'pon me

fields.english: Don't cut your nose to spite your face.
fields.creole: Na cut you' nose fo' pile you' face

fields.english: The lack of a tongue makes the cow unable to talk.
fields.creole: Na de lacking ob a tongue mek cow can't talk

fields.english: Don't put the dirty one where you dip your water.
fields.creole: Na dutty de pon' weh you dip you' watah

fields.english: Not every big head has sense.
fields.creole: Na ebery big head gat sense
