fields.english: Not every man who says "Good night" sleeps together.
fields.creole: Na ebery man wah say "Goo' night," a-sleep togeddah

fields.english: Not everything that goes to the market is for sale.
fields.creole: Na eberyt'ing wah go a market fo' sell

fields.english: Not everything that has sugar is sweet.
fields.creole: Na eberyt'ing wah gat sugah a-sweet

fields.english: Not everything you see, mouth to talk.
fields.creole: Na eberyt'ing you see, mout' fo' talk

fields.english: Don't consider yourself a big barrel, when a butter keg can hold you
fields.creole: Na fo'co youse'f a big puncheon, when buttah keg can hol' you

fields.english: Don't forget to light the fire before the water boils.
fields.creole: Na fo want ob fiah mek peas 'tan' lang fo bile

fields.english: It's not good to hold your neighbor's chair too much.
fields.creole: Na good fo' hot you matty chair too much

fields.english: Don't poke your friend's eye, so someone else won't poke yours.
fields.creole: Na jook 'tick a-you matty yeye, no so somebody else go jook a-fo' you

fields.english: Don't leave today's work for tomorrow.
fields.creole: Na leh to-day 'pile to-morrow

fields.english: Don't let the moonlight fool you, and give the dark night attitude.
fields.creole: Na mek moonlight fool you, an' gie dark night saucy

fields.english: Don't let a full belly fool you.
fields.creole: Na mek wan belly-full fool you

fields.english: Don't let sweet words fool you
fields.creole: Na mek sweet mout' fool you

fields.english: Don't let your ears pass your head.
fields.creole: Na mek you' aez pass you' head

fields.english: Not only monkeys make trousers, and then he can't fit them.
fields.creole: Na monkey 'lone does mek trouses, and fin' he can't fit am

fields.english: Not only a thief's dog barks at him.
fields.creole: Na only tief man daag bark 'pon

fields.english: The spread table cloth before pot done boil
fields.creole: Na 'pread table clot' befo' pat done bile

fields.english: Don't put on a long coat and smoke a cigarette when you go to the water mama dance.
fields.creole: Na put on long coat an' smoke cigah when you go a-watah mamma dance

fields.english: Don't put on Sunday clothes on a weekday, okay?
fields.creole: Na put on Sunday clo'es 'pon week-a-day 'kin

fields.english: Don't push your hand in the hot saucepan.
fields.creole: Na shub you' han' a-matty saucepan

fields.english: Don't stop to pack when you are running for the train.
fields.creole: Na 'tap fo' roll up 'tackin' when you a-run fo' train

fields.english: Don't judge a man by their appearance.
fields.creole: No tek man by dem look

fields.english: Don't take me for a fool.
fields.creole: Na tek me mek you' coo-coo pat

fields.english: Don't take out your guts and put in straw.
fields.creole: Na tek out you guts and put in 'traw

fields.english: Don't be ashamed to shake the cuckaba, my friend.
fields.creole: Na tek shame face shake cuckaba niggah han'

fields.english: Don't take advantage of your friend's trust.
fields.creole: Na tek you matty yeye fo' sleep wid

fields.english: Don't throw away dirty water until you get clean
fields.creole: Na t'row 'way dutty watah teh you get clean

fields.english: There is a dog named Pompey
fields.creole: Na wan daag name Pompey

fields.english: Nancy doesn't like to catch centipedes because they have long things.
fields.creole: Nancy no like fo' ketch marabuntah 'cause he gat lang 'ting

fields.english: Never the day canoe bore punt
fields.creole: Nebbah de day canoe bore punt

fields.english: Never eat crab-back and drink water.
fields.creole: Nebbah eat crab-back an' drink watah

fields.english: Never go at night to buy black cloth at the store.
fields.creole: Nebbah go a-night fo' buy black clat' a-'tore

fields.english: Never mind, the estate doesn't have a back dam.
fields.creole: Nebbah min'" mek estate no gat back-dam

fields.english: Never put fire to the fire.
fields.creole: Nebbah out fiah to fury

fields.english: Never sell everything as you buy it.
fields.creole: Nebbah sell eberyt'ing as you buy am

fields.english: Never push your head where you know you will get stuck.
fields.creole: Nebbah shub you' head weh you know you go fasten

fields.english: Never trouble trouble until trouble troubles you.
fields.creole: Nebbah trouble trouble till trouble trouble you

fields.english: Never throw away today what you might want tomorrow.
fields.creole: Nebbah t'row 'way to-day wha' you go want to-morrow

fields.english: Never throw away your walking stick until you cross the river.
fields.creole: Nebbah t'row 'way you walking 'tiek teh you cross ribah

fields.english: Never try to make H turn K.
fields.creole: Nebbah you try fo' mek H tu'n K

fields.english: The man is climbing up, his friend is pulling him down.
fields.creole: Niggah a-climb up, he matty a-pull he down

fields.english: Don't forget, the white person remembers
fields.creole: Niggah fo'get, Bacra 'membah

fields.english: The man lives happily, he will tell the governor "good morning"
fields.creole: Niggah libe happy, he go tell gubnah "ma'nin'

fields.english: The black man says, "Wait first"; the Portuguese says, "Especially"
fields.creole: Niggah say, "Wait fus"; Potagee say, "Specalah

fields.english: No better the barrel, no better the herring.
fields.creole: No bettah de barrel, no bettah de herrin'

fields.english: Nobody will beg when the rain comes.
fields.creole: Nobody go beg w'en rain da come

fields.english: There is a lot of noise in the market on non-selling days.
fields.creole: Noise a-market no selling day

fields.english: No catch, no have
fields.creole: No ketchee, no habee

fields.english: No longer fiddle, no longer dance
fields.creole: No langah fiddle, no langah dance

fields.english: When the window is not good, it makes a lot of noise when it's windy.
fields.creole: When windah na good, 'e mek 'nough noise a-win'

fields.english: Nonsense, man took a fork to eat soup.
fields.creole: Nonsense man tek fark fo' nyam soup

fields.english: No deceit, no living
fields.creole: No trick no libin'

fields.english: Now it's mango season; the neighbors are sitting down and chatting.
fields.creole: Now a mango season; matty no a-si' down matty doo' mout'

fields.english: Eat some, leave some for tomorrow
fields.creole: Nyam some, lef' some fo' to-morrow

fields.english: Okra and cassava can't make soup alone.
fields.creole: Ochro an' cassava can't mek soup a-wan pat

fields.english: Old firewood will soon catch fire.
fields.creole: Ol' fiah-'tick soon ketch

fields.english: The old granny is afraid of caterpillars; caterpillars are afraid of working their belly.
fields.creole: Ol' granny sweah fo' catapillah; catapillah sweah fo' wo'k he belly

fields.english: Old grudges make the bat lay eggs.
fields.creole: Ol' grudge mek bat lay egg

fields.english: Old grudges, new fights
fields.creole: Ol' grudge, new licks

fields.english: The old guitar plays a very nice tune.
fields.creole: Ol' guitar play bery nice chune

fields.english: The old rat eats new cheese.
fields.creole: Ol' rat eat new cheese

fields.english: Oh, things are bringing new ones
fields.creole: O tings a-bring new ones

fields.english: One egg can't give two chickens
fields.creole: One egg can't gie two chicken

fields.english: One finger can't catch a louse
fields.creole: One fingah can't ketch louse

fields.english: One fool makes many.
fields.creole: One fool mek many

fields.english: One man can't follow two calabashes
fields.creole: One man can't falla two gooby

fields.english: One man made a potato bank, and all the men dug it.
fields.creole: One man mek patata bank, all man dig am

fields.english: One man's money makes too many men cry.
fields.creole: One man money mek too much man cry

fields.english: One by one, dirty buildings are constructed.
fields.creole: One one dutty buil' dam

fields.english: One time nobody had finished it
fields.creole: One time nebbah done am

fields.english: One time might be a mistake, but two times is intentional.
fields.creole: One time see sa do, but two time is purpose

fields.english: Only cows know why, and flies feel sorry that God gave them a long tail.
fields.creole: Only cow know why, an' fly feel sarry God gie a long tail

fields.english: Only the knife knows what's inside the pumpkin's belly.
fields.creole: Only knife know wha' deh a-punckin belly

fields.english: The woman talks a lot, she put the fire on.
fields.creole: Ooman min' lang talk, he pat bu'n a-fiah

fields.english: Woman doesn't love man, he says "There is no place"
fields.creole: Ooman na lobe man, he say "Place na deh

fields.english: Open your eyes, you should know better.
fields.creole: Open you yeye, you sa sabby sense

fields.english: An orange never falls too far from the tree.
fields.creole: Orange nebbah fall too far from he tree

fields.english: The orange is yellow, but you don't know if it's sweet.
fields.creole: Orange yalla, but you na know if he sweet

fields.english: Out of the water, inside the mud
fields.creole: Out a-do watah, inside a-putto-putto

fields.english: Padlock your tongue, or it will lock you up.
fields.creole: Padlock you' tongue, or it lock you up

fields.english: Be patient, the man is driving the donkey.
fields.creole: Patience man dribe jackass

fields.english: The fish and the ghost went away, the ghost said "Where are we going to meet up?"
fields.creole: Patwa an' ouri fetch away, ouri say " Wai' awe go meet a-'tap aff

fields.english: It's better to pay first, more bad than don't pay at all.
fields.creole: Pay fus' mo' bad dan don't pay at all

fields.english: Payman never loses
fields.creole: Payman nebbah loss

fields.english: Pay today, trust tomorrow
fields.creole: Pay to-day, trus' to-morrow

fields.english: The child can't get milk, so he sucks on his grandmother.
fields.creole: Picknie can't get mamma, he suck granny

fields.english: Children can't hear, they must feel
fields.creole: Picknie can't heah, he mus' feel

fields.english: The child died on purpose, mother said to bury him on purpose.
fields.creole: Picknie dead fo' prupose, mamma sa bury am prupose

fields.english: The child cut their teeth too soon this time
fields.creole: Pieknie dis time cut dem yeye teet' too soon

fields.english: The child's head is messy, he doesn't want it to be combed.
fields.creole: Picknie head hab cra-cra, he no want am fo' comb

fields.english: Children know how to run, but don't know how to hide.
fields.creole: Picknie niggah know fo' run, but na know fo' hide

fields.english: Children don't understand "stand easy," he said "Oh, poor thing"
fields.creole: Picknie no heah "'Tan' easy," he sa heah "Aow, poo' ting

fields.english: Children should not take advantage of their father's poverty.
fields.creole: Picknie no tek lef' han' fo' t'row he daddy poverty

fields.english: The child asked his mother, "Why is your mouth so long?" The mother replied, "Well, child, you are growing."
fields.creole: Picknie pig say to mamma, "Wha' mek you' mout' long so?" Mamma say, "Wai' chil', you a-come

fields.english: The child who didn't hear the mother's story, he went to the other side with his jacket and left the door.
fields.creole: Picknie wah no yerry mamma 'tory he wan side jiggeh (jacket) go lef' a-doo'

fields.english: Pint pot turned down, gill pot turned up
fields.creole: Pint pot tu'n down, gill pot tu'n up

fields.english: The plantain cannot come green.
fields.creole: Plantain yalla can't come green

fields.english: Play with the monkey, but don't play with its tail.
fields.creole: Play wid monkey, but na play wid 'e tail

fields.english: Play with the puppy, the puppy licks your mouth.
fields.creole: Play wid puppy, puppy lick you mout'

fields.english: Play with a tiger's child, but don't play with its mother.
fields.creole: Play wid tigah picknie, but na play wid 'e mamma

fields.english: There are many ways to choke without hanging a rope around his neck.
fields.creole: Plenty way deh fo choke dang widout hangin' rope roun' he neck

fields.english: Poor is not a disease
fields.creole: Poo' is no disesse

fields.english: Poor man and rich man slave
fields.creole: Poo' man a-rich man slabe

fields.english: Poor man can't be angry, but he thinks it's hard
fields.creole: Poo' man can't bex, but he t'ink it haad

fields.english: Poor people make men greedy
fields.creole: Poo' mek man greedy

fields.english: Poor never sorry for himself
fields.creole: Poo' nebbah sorry fo' hese'f

fields.english: The pot is boiling, and the man is laughing.
fields.creole: Pot bile, man laugh

fields.english: Promises make friends; keeping them is important.
fields.creole: Promise get frien'; perform keep am

fields.english: Promise is like a butterfly, if you trust it, you might end up losing on your hand.
fields.creole: Promise is butterfly, put trus' deh, you loss 'pan you' han'

fields.english: Pumpkin never bear calabash
fields.creole: Pumpkin nebbah bear calabash

fields.english: Pumpkin never makes white soup
fields.creole: Pumpkin nebba mek white soup

fields.english: Purse full, plenty friends
fields.creole: Pu'se full, plenty frien'

fields.english:
Puss, cat
Creole: Puss, cat
fields.creole: Puss, cat

fields.english: A quick cent is better than a slow dollar
fields.creole: Quick cent bettah mo' 'an slow dallah

fields.english: The rabbit child's ears are never cut.
fields.creole: Rabbit pieknie aez nebbah cut

fields.english: It rained and the sun was shining, my grandmother Betsy's barrel is full.
fields.creole: Rain fall, day shine, me granny Betsy barrel a-full

fields.english: The rain is falling but the jug is not full, is the dew full?
fields.creole: Rain fall jug na full, dew sa full am?

fields.english: The rain fell, causing the sheep and goats to be in the pen.
fields.creole: Rain fall mek sheep an' goat a-wan pen

fields.english: The rain fell and wet the tiger, they call it a bush dog.
fields.creole: Rain fall wet tigah, dem call am bush-daag

fields.english: It's not raining, so the old lady isn't running.
fields.creole: Rain no fall, granny na run

fields.english: The ramgoat doesn't cry for horn, he cries for living.
fields.creole: Ramgoat no cry fo' ho'n, he cry fo' libin'

fields.english: Ramgoat said that his mother died soon, before the afternoon rain wet him.
fields.creole: Ramgoat say he soonah he mamma dead, befo' afternoon rain wet he

fields.english: The rat may forget, but the trap does not forget.
fields.creole: Rat a-fo'get, trap na fo'get

fields.english: The rat's tongue betrayed him
fields.creole: Ratta tongue sell he head

fields.english: Red dove is on the riverbank looking for ground dove.
fields.creole: Red dobe na a-obah ribah fo' look fo' groun' dobe

fields.english: Rice boiled, spoon last
fields.creole: Rice bile, 'poon las'

fields.english: The rich man is sick, the poor man is drunk.
fields.creole: Rich man sick, poo' man drunk

fields.english: Rock bottom riverbank doesn't feel the sun's heat.
fields.creole: Rock a-battam a-ribah no feel sun hot

fields.english: The rum is finished, the fun is finished
fields.creole: Rum done, fun done

fields.english: Run away from the coffin, or else you will end up with a ghost.
fields.creole: Run from coffin, you sa butt up wid jumby

fields.english: Run quickly, he is coming.
fields.creole: Run rum run he a-come

fields.english: Knowing something is always behind hand
fields.creole: Sabby somet'ing does always deh behin' han'

fields.english: Soft heart makes industry building broke
fields.creole: Saf' haat mek Industry buil'in' bruck

fields.english: The river runs deep safely
fields.creole: Saf'ly ribah run deep

fields.english: Safely, safely catch the monkey
fields.creole: Saf'ly saf'ly ketch monkey

fields.english: The dog's ears are safely and securely flown.
fields.creole: Saf'ly saf'ly fly done daag ear

fields.english: Same as the master, same as the man
fields.creole: Same like massa, same like man

fields.english: Service over church door lock
fields.creole: Sarvice obah chu'ch doo' lack

fields.english: Satisfied birds and hungry birds can't fly together.
fields.creole: Satisfy bi'd an' hungry bi'd can't fly togeddah

fields.english: Satisfy the bird and tell the hungry bird "Wait a little bit"
fields.creole: Satisfy bi'd tell hungry bi'd " Wai' lil bit

fields.english: Seek for see can't do better
fields.creole: Seca fo' see can't do bettah

fields.english: Sell your pork where you got your fat.
fields.creole: Sell you' po'k weh you get you fat

fields.english: Since the fowl doesn't have feathers, it wants corn.
fields.creole: Sensa fowl na wan' feddah, him wan' co'n

fields.english: Short pants for a little man
fields.creole: Shaat pa' a-kill man

fields.english: The short road is broken by the dog's foot
fields.creole: Shaat road a-bruck daag foot

fields.english: Shine your boots first before you shine your shoes.
fields.creole: Shine you' boots fus' befo' you shine you' matty wan

fields.english: Only the shoes know if the stockings have holes.
fields.creole: Shoes alone know if 'tockin's hab holes

fields.english: The sick mother called because she wants to hear your voice.
fields.creole: Sick mamma call, 'cause he want ketch you' voice

fields.english: The sick man is looking for a doctor.
fields.creole: Sick man look fo' dactah

fields.english: Sickness may be over, but trickery is not over.
fields.creole: Sick sa done, but trick can't done

fields.english: Silk and scarlet are seen by mother
fields.creole: Silk and 'carlet a-sin mamma

fields.english: Since bitter more than gall
fields.creole: Sin bittah mo' dan gall

fields.english: Since "Beg paadon" became popular, a little boy stepped on a big man's foot.
fields.creole: Since Beg paadon" come a-fashion, li'l boy mash big man foot

fields.english: Since the aboriginal Indian's hut burned down, there's no more fun to be had.
fields.creole: Since Buck benab bu'n, fai' play no deh

fields.english: Skillet can't tell that his bottom is black.
fields.creole: Skillet can't tell pat say 'e battam black

fields.english: Slowly bring down the heavy load
fields.creole: Slow motion bring heavy come down

fields.english: The little snake doesn't know its name until it goes to the dam.
fields.creole: Snake picknie na know 'e name teh 'e go a-dam

fields.english: If someone doesn't work, they won't eat the master's plantains.
fields.creole: Somebody no walk, he no eat massa plantain

fields.english: Some goats are running from the dog, but some are standing their ground against it.
fields.creole: Some goat a-run from daag, but some a-put he handle 'pon am

fields.english: Some men are fattening the hare for their meal.
fields.creole: Some man a-fatten haag fo' dem matty eat

fields.english: Sometimes white people have black hearts.
fields.creole: Sometimes white face carry black haat

fields.english: Something more than cane made him turn into sugar.
fields.creole: Somet'ing mo' dan cane mek he tu'n sugah

fields.english: The soup is cold, the dog is licking its mouth there.
fields.creole: Soup col', daag put mout' deh

fields.english: The soup with pork is not there itself.
fields.creole: Soup po'k no deh da se'f

fields.english: The man is not ashamed of sour grass.
fields.creole: Sour grass a man no a-shame

fields.english: Spit in the sky, it will fall on your face.
fields.creole: Spit a-de sky, he sa fall a-you' face

fields.english: Spiteful man like cow-down, hard on top, soft at the bottom
fields.creole: Spiteful man like cow-down, haad a-tap, saf' a-battam

fields.english: Spiteful man put pepper in his mouth to blow dirt out of his friend's eye.
fields.creole: Spiteful man put peppah da-he mout' fo' blow dutty out a-he matty yeye

fields.english: A quiet person is often a wise person
fields.creole: Still tongue keep wise head

fields.english: A stranger doesn't know the burial ground.
fields.creole: Stranger no know berrin' groun'

fields.english: Sucking teeth and rolling eyes at a man
fields.creole: Suck teet' an' cut yeye tek aff 'pon a man

fields.english: Sugar hogshead never kill hands
fields.creole: Sugah haagshead nebbah kill hanch

fields.english: The sun is hot today, it's scorching.
fields.creole: Sun hot da-wha, a stroke man

fields.english: The sun is not down, don't curse the mangy dog.
fields.creole: Sun na down, na cuss mangy daag

fields.english: The sun is not down yet, so the man is not finished crying.
fields.creole: Sun no down, man no done cry

fields.english: If he doesn't finish today, he will finish tomorrow.
fields.creole: Suppose he no done to-day, he sa done to-morrow

fields.english: Sweetheart, eat the sweet bread, you've finished it.
fields.creole: Sweet haat a-sweet bread, you nyam am he done

fields.english: Sweet talk brings the runaway back home.
fields.creole: Sweet mout' bring runaway niggah home

fields.english: The sweet orange is not falling to the ground.
fields.creole: Sweet orange no a-fall a-groun'

fields.english: Sweet soup makes you eat sour foofoo
fields.creole: Sweet soup mek you eat sour foofoo

fields.english: Talk is the last food.
fields.creole: Talk is de las' food

fields.english: Talking this and talking that, never mind your friend's business.
fields.creole: Talkin' dis an' talkin' dat, nebbah peep a-you matty pat

fields.english: Talk about the devil and you'll hear his wings
fields.creole: Talk ob de debil an you heah he wings

fields.english: Stand farther, see better
fields.creole: 'Tan' farra, see bettah

fields.english: Standing safely is better than begging for forgiveness.
fields.creole: 'Tan' saf'ly bettah dan beg paadon

fields.english: Stop the broken boat, the fish is getting away.
fields.creole: 'Tap-aff bruck, fish get 'way

fields.english: The tar rope and the man's back are not in agreement.
fields.creole: Tar rope an' man back na agree

fields.english: Teeth and tongue must bite
fields.creole: Teet' an' tongue mus' bite

fields.english: Thank you for killing my grandmother's cat.
fields.creole: Tenkee kill me granny cat

fields.english: The same tongue that drives the cow into the pen, can also drive it out.
fields.creole: The same tongue that drive cow a-pen, no so drive him out

fields.english: The quietest calf drinks the longest.
fields.creole: The stillest calf sucks the longest draught

fields.english: A thief stealing from another thief makes God Almighty laugh.
fields.creole: Tief from tief mek Garamighty laugh

fields.english: Time for mule, time for a long chain
fields.creole: Time fo' mule, time fo' lang chain

fields.english: A thief and a dog are not friends.
fields.creole: Tief man an' daag na frien'

fields.english: A thief doesn't like to see his friend walking with a big bag.
fields.creole: Tief man no like fo' see he matty walk with big bag

fields.english: A thief does not like the moon.
fields.creole: Tief man no like moon

fields.english: The tiger feels the fire on his tail, he calls for a cool breeze.
fields.creole: Tigah feel fiah a-he tail, he halla fo' cool breeze

fields.english: The tiger sent the dog, the dog sent his tail
fields.creole: Tigah sen' daag, daag sen' he tail

fields.english: The tiger stole corn, he got his own mark
fields.creole: Tigah tief co'n, he get he 'kin mark

fields.english: The tiger wanted to catch a fowlcock, so he told the country to turn.
fields.creole: Tigah wan' fo' ketch fowlcock, he tell am country tu'n

fields.english: Time has passed, but he has not returned.
fields.creole: Time a-go 'way, but he no a-come back

fields.english: The thing is asleep, don't wake it up.
fields.creole: T'ing a-sleep, no wake am

fields.english: That thing is to make the cow run away from her calf.
fields.creole: T'ing deh fo' mek cow run lef' he calf

fields.english: Today for you, tomorrow for me
fields.creole: To-day fo' you, to-morrow fo' me

fields.english: The tongue doesn't have teeth, but he bites for real.
fields.creole: Tongue na gat teet', but he bite fo' true

fields.english: Tom is drunk, but Tom is not a fool.
fields.creole: Tom drunk, but Tom no fool

fields.english: Too much old wood to be easily burned by fire.
fields.creole: Too much a ol' 'tump to be easily bu'n by fiah

fields.english: Too much teeth don't laugh
fields.creole: Too much 'kin teet' no laugh

fields.english: Too many rats don't dig deep holes.
fields.creole: Too much ratta don't dig deep hole

fields.english: Too much salt spoiled your soup.
fields.creole: Too much sal' 'pile you' soup

fields.english: Those trousers are too worn out.
fields.creole: Too much side bruck trouses

fields.english: Too much sitting down has broken my pants.
fields.creole: Too much si' down bruck breeches

fields.english: Too much water doesn't make good soup.
fields.creole: Too much watah no mek good soup

fields.english: Storytelling won't fill your stomach
fields.creole: 'Tory a-mout no load you' 'tomach

fields.english: Tell the bus driver to let the woman know
fields.creole: Tory bus' as you leh woman know

fields.english: The story is old, it's not interesting.
fields.creole: Tory ol', he no sweet

fields.english: Three silver fish cannot make one Congo fish.
fields.creole: Tree silver fish cant mek one Congo fish

fields.english: Tiral mek menshan
fields.creole: Trial makes mention

fields.english: Trouble in the bush, a monkey brings it to the house.
fields.creole: Trouble a-deh a-bush, a monkey a-bring am a-house

fields.english: Trouble comes quickly, but it leaves slowly
fields.creole: Trouble come 'pon horseback, he go 'way 'pon foot

fields.english: Trouble walks on legs, scandal has wings.
fields.creole: Trouble go 'pon legs, 'candal hab wings

fields.english: Trouble makes old women tired
fields.creole: Trouble mek ol' ooman trat

fields.english: Trouble must knock at every man's door.
fields.creole: Trouble mus' knack at all man doo' mout'

fields.english: Trouble doesn't come all at once like rain.
fields.creole: Trouble no set like rain

fields.english: Throw a rock at the crow, it cries "Quee," that's when it gets hit.
fields.creole: T'row rockstone a-haag 'ty, haag cry "Quee," dá him it knack

fields.english: Try your boots first before you give another man to stretch them.
fields.creole: Try you' boots fus' befo' you gie naddah man fo' 'tretch am

fields.english: Two captains can't steer one ship.
fields.creole: Two cap'n can't 'teer wan ship

fields.english: Two hills can't meet together, but two people can.
fields.creole: Two hill can't meet togeddah, but two man can

fields.english: Two men are telling a long story
fields.creole: Two man a-mek lang 'tory

fields.english: A wise person cannot live in the same house as a foolish person.
fields.creole: Two sense man can't libe a-wan house

fields.english: A foolish person cannot change their nature.
fields.creole: Two sense man can't change half-bitt

fields.english: Two things are running, one must win
fields.creole: Two t'ing a-run, one must' win

fields.english: A caba face no caba heart
fields.creole: Ugly face no ugly heart

fields.english: Ugly tells handsome, "Frighten this for me"
fields.creole: Ugly tell han'some, "Friken dis fo' me

fields.english: A reluctant man's nose must bleed
fields.creole: Unwillin' man nose mus' bleed

fields.english: The vat is not open enough time, dry weather like rainy weather.
fields.creole: Vat no a-open 'nough time, dry weddah like rain weddah

fields.english: What's coming, wait, do you see him?
fields.creole: Wah a-come, wai', you sa see am

fields.english: What are they crying for, they are feeling it.
fields.creole: Wah a-cry, á dem a-feel am

fields.english: What luck did he have to win?
fields.creole: Wah gat luck sa win

fields.english: What doesn't have feet must go before.
fields.creole: Wah na gat foot mus' go befo'

fields.english: Walking for nothing is better than sitting down for nothing.
fields.creole: Walk fo' not'in' bettah dan si' down fo' not'in'

fields.english: Wasteful man's money goes like butter against the sun.
fields.creole: Was'eful man money go like buttah 'gainst de sun

fields.english: Wash your own face before you wash your friend's face.
fields.creole: Wash you' own face befo' you wash you' matty wan

fields.english: Wash your own sore before you look at someone else's.
fields.creole: Wash you' own sore befo' you look you' matty wan

fields.english: Water around fire
fields.creole: Watah a-out fiah

fields.english: Water is not running for no reason.
fields.creole: Watah no a-'tink a-jar fo' not'in'

fields.english: The water has no bottom
fields.creole: Watah no gat battam

fields.english: Water was thrown away, but the jug didn't break.
fields.creole: Watah t'row 'way jug no broke

fields.english: Water thrown away on the ground cannot be picked up again.
fields.creole: Watah t'row way na groun' can't pick up again

fields.english: The water was running over the river last year and it's running again this year.
fields.creole: Watah wah run a-ribah las' yeah na a-run dis yeah

fields.english: Water washes, water falls
fields.creole: Watah wash, watah fall

fields.english: Watch the lion, but don't let him watch you.
fields.creole: Watch lion, but na mek he watch you

fields.english: The wooden house has ears
fields.creole: Wattle 'ouse gat yase

fields.english: Where the cow is tied, there she is grazing.
fields.creole: Weh cow tie, á-deh he a-graze

fields.english: Where the horse goes, the donkey goes too.
fields.creole: Weh haas go, jackass sa go too

fields.english: Where there is plenty of water, more water runs.
fields.creole: Weh plenty watah deh mo' watah run

fields.english: Where the top of the week, a goat is bored.
fields.creole: Weh tap-off weak á-deh a goat does bore

fields.english: Well, can't let very well alone.
fields.creole: Well can't let bery well alone

fields.english: What's going on, let him go
fields.creole: Wha' a-go, leh he go

fields.english: What's happening, look out quickly before he passes
fields.creole: Wha' a-pass, look out quick befo' he pass

fields.english: What comes from the devil's back goes under his belly.
fields.creole: Wha' come from de debil back go undah he belly

fields.english: What comes out of your belly will not go into mine.
fields.creole: Wha' come out a-you belly no a-go in a-me own

fields.english: What goes out must come in
fields.creole: Wha' come out sa go in

fields.english: What is the house for you, what is the bush for us
fields.creole: Wha' da-house a-fo' you, wha' da-bush a-f' awe

fields.english: What's on the ground for the dog, not all the dog will pick it up.
fields.creole: Wha' deh a-groun' fo' daag, but no all daag a-pick am

fields.english: Where there is a stick head, there is a snake head
fields.creole: Wah' deh a stick head, deh a-snake head

fields.english: What's in your belly doesn't come out of your mouth.
fields.creole: Wha' deh a-you belly na mek am pass t'rough you' mout'

fields.english: What's in the old goat must be in the child
fields.creole: Wha' deh in de ol' goat mus' be in de picknie

fields.english: What fell into the fire, you saw find it as ashes.
fields.creole: Wha' fall a-fiah you sa fin' am a-ashes

fields.english: What falls from the head goes to the shoulder.
fields.creole: Wha' fall from head go a-shouldah

fields.english: What was the fly doing before the cow got a sore eye?
fields.creole: Wha' fly bin a-do befo' cow get sore yeye?

fields.english: What can a fly do with a turtle's back?
fields.creole: Wha' fly can do wid tu'tle' back?

fields.english: What happens to a black chicken happens to a white chicken.
fields.creole: Wha' happen to black fowl sa happen to white fowl

fields.english: What hurt my eye made my nose run water.
fields.creole: Wha' hu't yeye mek nose run watah

fields.english: What was the Mahaica man doing before the Munro glanders horse died?
fields.creole: Wha' Mahaica niggah bin a-do befo' Munro glandas haas dead?

fields.english: What movement quicksilver has at the bottom, he doesn't have at the top.
fields.creole: Wha' motion quicksilver got a-battam, he na gat a-sluice

fields.english: What's not good for breakfast is not good for dinner.
fields.creole: Wha' no good fo' breakfas' no good fo' dinnah

fields.english: What happened to chase him, let him go, what's coming to see him, wait for him.
fields.creole: Wha' pass chase am let 'e go, wha' a-come si down wait am

fields.english: What makes sense to a snake's head, the same makes sense to a stick's head.
fields.creole: Wha' sense deb a-snake head, de same deh a-bostick-head

fields.english: What does that have to do with the cow-fly?
fields.creole: Wha' some'ting tocle sa do wid cow-fly?

fields.english: What the eye doesn't see, the heart doesn't burn
fields.creole: Wha' yeye no see haat no bu'n

fields.english: What the ears don't hear, the heart doesn't burn
fields.creole: Wha' ears no heah haat no bu'n

fields.english: What your eyes didn't see, your mouth didn't run water.
fields.creole: Wha' you' eye no see you mout' no run watah

fields.english: What you gain in dancing, you lose in shuffling
fields.creole: Wha' you gain in jigging you lose in shuffling

fields.english: What did you put in the pickle, it's so delicious
fields.creole: Wha' you put in de pickle nebbah 'pile

fields.english: What's too heavy for your hand, roll it on the ground.
fields.creole: Wha' too heaby fo' you han' roll am a-groun'

fields.english: What you lost in the saucepan, you must find in the bottom of the coal pot.
fields.creole: Wha' you loss a-saucepan you mus' fin' a-bottom coal pot

fields.english: When Buck wants to harm you, he says "Fair play is not deceitful"
fields.creole: When Buck wan' a-damage you he say "Fair play no pra pra

fields.english: When building a fire, the master asked the laborer to catch fish.
fields.creole: When buil'in' a-ketch fiah massa beg labrah

fields.english: When two bulls meet, they call each other "Bro"
fields.creole: When bull an' bull meet dey call matty "Bro

fields.english: When two men are gossiping, the boss has no business there.
fields.creole: When bull an' bull a-chat, capoon na gat business deh

fields.english: When cassava and okra meet together, the pot must burn.
fields.creole: When cassada an' ochro meet a-pat, pat mus' bu'n

fields.english: When a cat's belly is full, he says "Rats think"
fields.creole: When cat belly full, he say "Ratta 'tink

fields.english: When the cat doesn't get milk, he remembers the bird in the bush.
fields.creole: When cat na get milk, he 'membah bi'd a-bush

fields.english: When the carrion crow gets a tickle in its eye, it thinks it's the governor.
fields.creole: When claninclo get yeye-tickle he t'ink hese'f gubnah

fields.english: When the carrion crow eats his fill, he shakes his wings on his mate.
fields.creole: When claninclo nyam belly-full, he shake 'e wing 'pon 'e matty

fields.english: When the chiggah's foot is swollen, toughen it with cotton.
fields.creole: When chiggah foot a rattan 'tuff am wid cattan

fields.english: When a coconut falls from a tree, it can't be put back.
fields.creole: When coc'nut fall from tree he can't fasten back

fields.english: When a cockroach gives a dance, he doesn't ask the fowl.
fields.creole: When cockroach gie dance, he no hax fowl

fields.english: When a poor man gets money, he bribes the governor.
fields.creole: When cocoby man get money, 'e shake gubnah han'

fields.english: When one man meets another, he says "There's no time."
fields.creole: When cuffman meet cuffman he say "Time no deh

fields.english: When the dog gets hit, he tucks his tail under his belly and runs and screams for real, but be careful when he comes back.
fields.creole: When daag get lick he put 'e tail under he belly an' run an' halla fo' true, but look sharp when he come back

fields.english: When the pork is sweet, the man keeps it in his mouth for a long time.
fields.creole: When flesin po'k sweet, man a-keep am lang a-he mout'

fields.english: When one chicken meets another in a chicken's country, they tell each other "Surprise!"
fields.creole: When fowl an' fowl meet a-fowl country, tara tell tara "So by

fields.english: When the rooster gets drunk, he forgets that there is a black handled knife in the kitchen.
fields.creole: When fowl-cock get grog, he fo'get say "black 'andle knife deh a-kitchen

fields.english: When a fowl gets teeth and a dog eats a razor
fields.creole: When fowl get teet' an' daag nyam razah

fields.english: When the ibis sees a fish, it forgets that the gun is there.
fields.creole: When galin see fish, he fo'get say "Gun deh

fields.english: When a goat goes down a hill, it rolls without the wind blowing it.
fields.creole: When goat down wan' roll he roll widout win' blow am

fields.english: When the horse is not there, the donkey takes the first place.
fields.creole: When haas na deh, jackass mek fus' place

fields.english: When he calls God's name, that's when he lies.
fields.creole: When he a-call Gad name, á de time he lie

fields.english: When he is there, he is there, when he is not there, he is not there.
fields.creole: When he deh he deh, when he na deh he na deh

fields.english: When herring fat is burning, everyone can smell it.
fields.creole: When herrin' fat a-bu'n, na all man a-smell am

fields.english: When a hungry person catches a coolie, he is glad to eat pork.
fields.creole: When hungry ketch coolie, he glad fo' eat po'k

fields.english: When a donkey kicks a man, the man shouldn't bother kicking it back.
fields.creole: When jackass kick man, man mus'n't baddah kick am back

fields.english: When a young boy puts on adult trousers, he must accept the consequences.
fields.creole: When li'l boy put on big man trouses, wha' he get he mus' take

fields.english: When a small dog has a big liver, he will die before his time.
fields.creole: When li'l daag gat big libah, he go dead befo' 'e time

fields.english: When the little boy wants to run, give him a long rope.
fields.creole: When li'l niggah wan' run, gie am lang rope

fields.english: When a man is going to eat at a woman's house, he must let the woman eat first.
fields.creole: When man a-go eat a-wan ooman 'ouse, he mus' leh a ooman eat fus'

fields.english: When a man is going to jump a fence, he must look good before he jumps.
fields.creole: When man a-go jump fence, he must look good befo' he jump

fields.english: When a man is writing, don't touch his pen.
fields.creole: When man a-write, no touch he pen

fields.english: When a man buys butter, his friend sticks his finger deep into it.
fields.creole: When man buy buttah, he matty chook he fingah deep

fields.english: When a man has a good life, he calls God "Congah"
fields.creole: When man get good libin' he call God "Congah

fields.english: When a man makes himself sugar, his friends will definitely take advantage of him.
fields.creole: When man mek hese'f sugah, 'e matty suck am fo' true

fields.english: When a man doesn't have a match, he takes a fire stick to light the lamp.
fields.creole: When man na gat match he tek fiah-'tick fo' light lamp

fields.english: When a man sucks sugar cane, he crushes the peel on the ground.
fields.creole: When man suck cane, 'e mash 'e pilin' a-groun.'

fields.english: When a man wants to beat a dog, he finds a stick quickly.
fields.creole: When man wan' fo' beat daag, he 'fin' 'tick quick

fields.english: When my foot itches, it's a sign that I need to go for a walk.
fields.creole: When me foot itch me, a sign me go walk

fields.english: When I left my hand itched, money was coming.
fields.creole: When me lef' han' 'cratch me, money a-come

fields.english: When my eyes are dancing, it's a sign that I will cry.
fields.creole: When me yeye a-dance, a sign me go cry

fields.english: When one person hurts you, everyone else gets upset
fields.creole: When one toot' hu't you, all de res' bex

fields.english: When the bird sees food, it forgets to look at the bottom.
fields.creole: When patwa see bait, 'e fo'get say "'Ook de a-battam

fields.english: When a puppy gets plenty of milk, he makes a face at salt soup.
fields.creole: When puppy get plenty milk, he mek up he face 'pon sal' soup

fields.english: When it's drizzling rain, the devil and his wife are fighting for the ham bone.
fields.creole: When rain a-drizzle, debil an' he wife a-fight fo' ham bone

fields.english: When it rains and the sun is shining, the devil is beating his wife.
fields.creole: When rain fall an' sun shining, debil licking he wife

fields.english: When a rat sees a cat, it never laughs.
fields.creole: When rat see cat, 'e nebbah laugh

fields.english: When the saucepan lost its cover, everyone looked inside.
fields.creole: When saucepan loss he cobah, all man a-peep inside

fields.english: When a sore can't get better, a person has to sit down and bear it.
fields.creole: When sore can't get bettah, man gat fo' si' down bear am

fields.english: When the tiger gets old, the dog barks after him.
fields.creole: When ti'gah get ol', daag ba'k aftah am

fields.english: When the tiger is not there, the monkey gives a ball.
fields.creole: When tigal na deh, monkey gie ball

fields.english: When the tiger is sick, they are done for money.
fields.creole: When tigah sick, deer dun am fo' money

fields.english: When trouble comes, he doesn't blow his own trumpet.
fields.creole: When trouble come, he no blow 'e shell

fields.english: When trouble catches a white person, monkey breeches fit him.
fields.creole: When trouble ketch Bacra, monkey breeches fit am

fields.english: When trouble catches a man, he stands up and faces it; When trouble catches a woman, she sits down and thinks about it.
fields.creole: When trouble ketch man, he 'tan' up an' 'taggah; When trouble ketch ooman, him si-down an' considah

fields.english: When two big bottles are on the table, the little one has no business.
fields.creole: When two big bottle deh a-table, little wan no bu'iness

fields.english: When the tub doesn't have a hoop, it must break down.
fields.creole: When tub na got hoople, he mus' bruck down

fields.english: When two dogs quarrel, the tomcat stands on one side.
fields.creole: When two daag get quarrel, Tom cat 'tan wan side

fields.english: When your brother is in trouble, don't laugh at him.
fields.creole: When you bruddah soak, don' laugh he

fields.english: When you're dead, you don't know, and when you know, you're already dead.
fields.creole: When you' dead you no sabby, an' when you sabby, you dead done

fields.english: When you get a donkey to ride, ride it for real.
fields.creole: When you get jackass fo' ride, ride am fo' true

fields.english: When you go into the bush, don't walk the same road back.
fields.creole: When you go a-bush, no walk same road come back

fields.english: When you go to the countryside where they are dancing with one foot, dance with one foot too.
fields.creole: When you go a-country weh dem a-dance wid one foot, dance wid one foot too

fields.english: When you go to a friend's house, leave your stomach behind.
fields.creole: When you go a-frien' house, lef' you' 'tomach behin'

fields.english: When you have money, the door is open; when you don't have, it's shut.
fields.creole: When you gat money, doo' open; when you no gat, he shut

fields.english: When you have the devil to deal with, feed him with a long spoon.
fields.creole: When you hab de debil fo' deal wid, feed am wid long 'poon

fields.english: When your hand is yellow, the dog acts like that.
fields.creole: When you' han' yalla, daag mek so

fields.english: When you kill the bush cow, be careful how you carry it in the canoe.
fields.creole: When you kill comma, min' how you carry am a-canoe

fields.english: When you leave, don't forget to say "Good night"
fields.creole: When you lef' wake house, no say "Goo' night

fields.english: When you step on a dog, put on your shoes.
fields.creole: When you mash daag, put on you' shoes

fields.english: When your own louse bites you, it bites you for real.
fields.creole: When you own louse bite you, he bite you fo' true

fields.english: When you sit down, keep your mouth shut, always leave room for the ghost to pass.
fields.creole: When you si' down doo' mout', always lef' room fo' jumby pass

fields.english: White dog doesn't eat white bread, but black sells his friend for one cent.
fields.creole: White daag no nyam white dang, but black sell he matty fo'one cent

fields.english: Whoever the cap fits, let them wear it.
fields.creole: Who de cap fit, leh 'e draw de 'tring

fields.english: Whoever follows me, they burn the wood for mutton.
fields.creole: Who falla me, dem bu'n dem wood fo' mutton

fields.english: He who has the longest pole, he sounds the deepest.
fields.creole: Who hab de langes' pole á he a-soun' deepes.'

fields.english: If you don't know death, then look at sleep.
fields.creole: Who no know dead, leh 'e look 'pon sleep

fields.english: Whoever plays with the puppy will get bitten by the fleas.
fields.creole: Who play wid de puppy get bit wid de fleas

fields.english: Who put plantain or cassava flour in the sun, he is looking for rain.
fields.creole: Who put gungotay a-sun, á he a-look fo' rain

fields.english: Wind blowing hard, what do you think, sister?
fields.creole: Win' blow mo'tah, wha' you t'ink a-sifta?

fields.english: Wind can't pass between them
fields.creole: Win' can't pass between dem

fields.english: Without a support, nothing.
fields.creole: Wit'out a back stap, not'in'

fields.english: A worker is not a lazy person
fields.creole: Wo'kman no' dam wo'kman

fields.english: Work never kills a man, but money kills him.
fields.creole: Wo'k nebbah a kill man, but bungo (money) a-kill am

fields.english: The woman is deceitful like a star apple leaf
fields.creole: Woman 'ceiful like 'tar apple leaf

fields.english: A woman's mouth runs like a sick person drinking salt.
fields.creole: Woman mout' run like sick niggah drink sal's

fields.english: A woman's mouth runs just like a horse's trot.
fields.creole: Woman mout' run same like haas a-trat

fields.english: Women don't die for real, they open their eyes to hear a man's story.
fields.creole: Woman no die fo' true, he open he yeye fo' heah man 'tory

fields.english: A woman's tongue is truly sweet.
fields.creole: Woman tongue sweet fo' true

fields.english: A woman who lives alone is not a woman.
fields.creole: Woman wah lib a-no house, a no woman

fields.english: Worst payment, Captain Trust
fields.creole: Wors' payman, Cap'n Trus'

fields.english: Yellow lime is falling from the tree, and green lime is falling too.
fields.creole: Yalla lime a-fall a-tree, an' green lime a-fall too

fields.english: The yellow man doesn't know his race because he's a thief.
fields.creole: Yalla nigah na know e' race teh he tief

fields.english: The young girl and the important storyteller will soon break down.
fields.creole: Yanga gal an' big 'tory man soon bruck down

fields.english: The young girl is full of emotions
fields.creole: Yanga gal full ob motions

fields.english: The young girl's heart is like sand at the seaside, you write your name and the first wave comes and washes it out.
fields.creole: Yanga gal haat like san' a-seaside, you write you' name deb fus' wave come wash am out

fields.english: The wild animal doesn't care if the guinea bird is a watchman.
fields.creole: Yawarri no ca'e if guinea bi'd a-watchman

fields.english: Hear me, hear you
fields.creole: Yaw yo, yaw me

fields.english: You work in a sugar plantation, you can't get dirty with paint.
fields.creole: You a-wo'k a-sugah laf', you 'kin can't nassy wid paint

fields.english: You better hang a man before you frighten him.
fields.creole: You bettah hang a man befo' you frighten he

fields.english: You call the tiger master, he will attack you, so be careful
fields.creole: You call tigah massa, he a-haul out he nail 'pon you, so call

fields.english: You can't tell from looking at someone if they are a thief.
fields.creole: You can't tell from cat 'kin if he a-tief

fields.english: You are the mat, I am the ground.
fields.creole: You de mat, me de groun.'

fields.english: You eat a sweet chicken egg, but the chicken feels it.
fields.creole: You eat fowl egg a-sweet, but fowl a-feel am

fields.english: Yu inimii cyaan hu't yu
fields.creole: You enemy can't hu't you

fields.english: Are your eyes really deceiving me?
fields.creole: You' eyes really pass me?

fields.english: You are like two-faced under one hat.
fields.creole: You is like two faces undah one cap

fields.english: You play your drum, you dance yourself
fields.creole: You knack you' drum, you dance youse'f

fields.english: You jump half, you fall into a trench
fields.creole: You leap 'alf, you fall a-trench

fields.english: You are looking for trouble to break your own head.
fields.creole: You look fo' 'tick fo' bruck you' own head

fields.english: Your friend's business is none of your concern, you left your tools in the grass.
fields.creole: You' matty bu'iness you a-min, you lef' you dinkies a-grass

fields.english: You make your bed safe, you can lay down safely.
fields.creole: You mek you' bed saf', you sa lay down saf

fields.english: You might run like a sore foot.
fields.creole: You mout' run like a sore foot

fields.english: If you don't know, ask someone who does.
fields.creole: You na know jumby, ask cow

fields.english: You're not important to me, I'm not thinking about you
fields.creole: You na rattan fo' me, me no 'tinkin' fo' you

fields.english: You can't give biscuits, don't make someone lose bread.
fields.creole: You no able gie biscuit, no mek somebody loss bread

fields.english: You don't clear the ground for monkeys to run on.
fields.creole: You no cleah groun' fo' monkey run 'pon

fields.english: Don't throw the aboriginal Indian into the water.
fields.creole: You no t'row Buck a-watah

fields.english: Close your eyes, and open your eyes, neighbor.
fields.creole: You own shut you' yeye, matty own open you' yeye

fields.english: You know how to run, but you don't know how to hide.
fields.creole: You sabby run, you no sabby hide

fields.english: You see Matty's face, you don't see his heart.
fields.creole: You see matty face, you no see he haat

fields.english: If you see smoke, there's fire.
fields.creole: You see smoke, fiah deh

fields.english: Don't use my name to make a pass
fields.creole: You no tek me name mek pass

fields.english: The Zulu man is crying for living, he is not crying for hand.
fields.creole: Zulu man a-cry fo' libin', he no a-cry fo' han.'
